Atop the mantle are photos of Callandro's relatives for the whole of it, save one photograph of the exterior of Callandro's Cauldron Collage. Above the mantle is a large, shifting painting of wizards and witches standing around a cauldron, brewing something green. A large door of the same wood as the mantle is in the southwest corner of the room, and the only other seeming exit is the staircase in the northeast corner of the room.

room.name: Stairwell Suchard's Shoes
room.desc: This tall room resembles a square well-shaft. Most of the space is given over to a rickety, spiral staircase that leads from the trap door in the floor to an identical, wooden door in the ceiling. Dusty, wooden shelves, piled high with boxes, line the walls. The aroma of new leather and old cardboard hangs heavily in the air. Old-fashioned oil lamps cast a dim, but warm light, illuminating the dust motes that drift lazily about the room.

extradesc.desc: Tidy stacks of multicoloured boxes cover every square inch of shelf space. Most of the cardboard containers bear pictures of footwear in a range of sizes and styles. One of the smallest boxes is emblazoned with the name 'Pixiepins', and proudly bears the indication 'Size 1/6', along with a miniscule illustration of a tiny slipper with a high heel. The label on the largest box declares it contains 'ThunderToes - Size 762'.

roomecho.desc: A tiny mouse peers out from behind a box, squeaks in alarm, and disappears back into the shadows.
A sudden furry of tiny squeaks issues from behind the stacked boxes. The sounds end as suddenly as they started.

room.name: Gringotts - Inner Doors
room.desc: Past the burnished, bronze, entrance doors is another set of doors, these made of highly polished silver. A rhyme is engraved with curly writing upon them. On either side of the doors a goblin is positioned, dressed in their elaborate gold and scarlet uniforms. They stand upon highly polished white marble floors, inlaid with intricate designs. On to the north, past the silver doors, is the main chamber of Gringotts. To the south are the Gringotts steps.

extradesc.desc: A rhyme is engraved upon the gleaming silver doors. It reads: "Enter, stranger, but take heed Of what awaits the sin of greed For those who take, but do not earn Must pay most dearly in their turn. So if you seek beneath our floors A treasure that was never yours, Thief, you have been warned, beware Of finding more than treasure there."

room.name: Madam Malkin's Robes for All Occasion
room.desc: The shop front of Madam Malkin's is very neat, albeit a bit dusty. West of the front door is an old, antique desk of mahogany, presumably to match the floors. Three long shelves sit in the center of the room, parallel to the side walls. The only curves that seem to be in the shop are the billowing folds of the robes hanging. In the back portion of the shop are three, squat stools and three gilded mirrors reflecting them.

room.name: Andros' Attire
room.desc: This huge shop is immaculate. The purple berber carpet covers the floor, wall to wall, and is stainless. The white walls and ceiling have white walls covered in a pattern of off-white swirls, as if from the sea. Rectangle mahogany tables with black tops are arranged all around the shop, holding up folded sweaters, shirts, pants, and socks of all colors. A simple, square cashier's stand is near the back, with what looks like a muggle cash register.

room.name: Ollivander's - Front Shop
room.desc: Ollivander's could be mistaken for a very dusty library. The shop is immaculate beyond the dust, the long thin boxes on the shelves are stacked to the ceiling in neat rows and columns. The dark wooden walls are plain and uncovered except for a portrait of a man with a very large handlebar moustache and a few sconces lighting the dim room. Along the west wall is a spindly chair, that looks as though it was squashed at one time.

room.name: The Quibbler
room.desc: The curved walls that enclose this cluttered space are covered in maps and photographs, clumped by topic. There may once have been windows, but they have long since been papered over with layer upon layer of information for potential articles. A bobbing group of candles flock in the centre of the Q-shaped space, illuminating everything with a furtive, shifting light. The inner edge of the round door in the north wall is rimmed by a dozen locks of all types and materials. A handwritten note on a dirty scrap of parchment is pinned to the centre. Along the bottom curve of the 'Q', cluttered desks and cabinets balance, unaffected by the sloping floor. To the west of the room, an alcove juts out beyond the exterior wall, its inclined bottom revealing it to be the tail of the 'Q'.

extradesc.desc: This mural covers the cream-coloired wall up past the front desk. A piece of parchment with illegible writing on it spins around the red words, "The Quibbler". Underneath it lies the Quibbler's motto, in blue, "Truth and Balance."

These candles bob up and down like butterbeer corks floating on a choppy sea. Faintly golden and as thick as a man's wrist, they exude the aroma of warm honey. Stamped on each waxen base are the words 'Wrail & Wrobert's Wrackspurt Repellant Light'.

Clusters of photographs, notes, and ragged-edged newspaper articles surround maps affixed to the walls with Spell-O-Tape. Red string and thumbtacks connect each piece of supporting information to a corresponding spot on the appropriate map. Illegible, scrawled notes, in a dozen colours of ink, cover maps and articles alike. Each grouping bears a carefully-printed title in capital letters. Typical examples are 'MoM HELIOPATH ATTACKS'; 'CRUMPLE-HORNED SNORKACK SIGHTINGS' and 'CASES OF LOSER'S LURGY: WALES'. Taped under the titles are slips of yellow parchment reading 'May? ' or 'September!!! '.

Tilted wildly with the curve of the floor, the battered furniture is covered with precarious piles of parchment. The 'IN' tray on the ancient desk is overflowing with unopened letters, scrolls, and bundles of photographs. Overstuffed wire baskets with labels like 'Auror's Conspiracy' and 'Blibbering Humdinger Sightings' cover the rest of the surface. Tucked into a container marked 'Alarming News about the MoM' is a dried-out ham sandwich, adorned with wilted lettuce and crusty mustard. Ragged file folders peek out of the partially-open drawers of the cabinets. Stray pages and fuzzy photographs protrude at rakish angles.

The outward-sloping, tapering alcove serves as a storage area for the Quibbler office. Bulging, cardboard cartons are stacked from floor to ceiling, interspersed with brown paper sacks of parchment and elderly manila envelopes. Tied bundles of 'Quibbler' back-issues are stuffed in every spare crevice. Projecting out over the top is what appears to a dilapidated, black umbrella, with several broken spokes.

This tattered and stained piece of parchment shows wide creases indicative of being folded and unfolded many times. The handwriting is faint, faded by time and handling, but still legible. "Embrace possibility," it says. "The truth is out there."

roomecho.desc: A floating candle darts through the room, hovering over the desk before returning to the rest of the levitating lights.

room.name: Eeylops Owl Emporium
room.desc: This dark wooded shop is absolutely packed, literally to the rafters. The ceiling is cluttered with all cages of hooting, fluttering, squawking owls. All along the floor are supplies to feed and groom your owl, along with white splotches dotting the ground. On the back wall is a large mesh cage filled with mice, all scurrying ontop of themselves. Amid piles of boxes there is a dark wood counter near the door, with a cash register on top of it. Behind it is a grungy cashier and a stand selling owl treats.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: This subterranean chamber is filled with the echoing sound of dripping water. The air is damp, permeated with a foul miasma of sewage and decay. Dimly lit by a pair of torches fastened to the wall, the tunnel has taken on a sulfurous cast, the shadows writhing as the flames flicker. To the east and west, the shadows close in on the two passageways exiting the room. The arched, brick ceiling is stained and liberally pimpled with gathering droplets of cloudy fluid. The walls are clammy from the humidity, the rough surface of the unfired bricks offering purchase to all manner of slime, mould, and fungi. Slate slabs, treacherously slick in the damp environment, serve as a floor. A rust-stained, iron grate in the centre of the tunnel allows a glimpse of what lies beneath.

extradesc.desc: The heavy stench is stronger near this grille of welded iron bars. Edges embedded firmly beneath the flagstones, it is still sturdy, though the constant exposure to moisture has caused rust to bloom in convoluted shapes at each joint. A hand-span below the diamond-shaped openings, a sluggish river of dark fluid drains past, floating solids dragging back at the edges.

roomecho.desc: A droplet of filthy water falls from the ceiling. It catches the torchlight; for an instant, it is a tongue of murky flame.

room.name: Sewer Beneath Zambrovski's Pub
room.desc: The walls of this narrow passageway are huge, roughly hewn blocks of yellowing stone. Foul-looking iron spouts, dripping incessantly, project from the filthy gloom at random intervals. Embedded between the stones are small, dimly glowing bricks; the sickly, amber light they emit failing in its savage attempt to reach the ceiling or the floor. Overhead, the ceiling is either so pitch as to consume all light that touches it or permanently obscured in shadow, giving the impression of infinite height. A strong, acrid stench of beer, rotting wood, and urine hangs in the air. To the east, the blasted ruins of a wall mark where the passageway was once blocked. Thin, wispy ground mist spirals and creeps around the rubble, continuing westward as the tunnel opens out.

extradesc.desc: Leering like vicious mouths from the walls, the drains constantly vomit forth liquid of disgusting colours and consistencies. Each spout ends in a ragged edge, seemingly waiting to sink iron jaws into anything straying too close.
Upon closer inspection, each brick seems to be made of several crystals bound together in clear mucus. The light they emit gently pulsates, making the whole tunnel seem to contract and grow.
It appears there was once a dividing wall in this section of tunnel. Now, only dust and fragments of stone remain, opening the way into the sewers beyond.
This mist blankets the ground here, sending creeping fingers of fog along every surface. The wispy tendrils have a hypnotic, determined caress, causing the mist to seem almost alive.

roomecho.desc: A heavy stream of rancid, dark liquid gushes from a spout and onto the barely-visible floor, eventually flowing into the surrounding tunnels.
A shower of ancient silt crumbles from the ceiling, dislodged by activity overhead.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Near Weasley's Wizarding Wheezes
room.desc: A worn cobblestone road lies ahead, chipping from use. Buildings can be seen on either side of the path. Loud bangs and shrieking whistles come from a building up north - the weather-beaten red paint is chipping off of the wooden slats of the building, and the roof is patched. There is smoke billowing from the chimney. Hooked precariously on a thin iron shaft above the door is a wooden sign, painted with bright yellow and blue wands. Weasley's Wizard Wheezes spreads out in bright green. *****WEASLEY'S MOVED TO COINCIDE WITH BOOK 6, WHICH SAYS THEY TURN LEFT INTO KA WHEN THEY LEAVE WWWs. ****** ***ALSO, MAKE SURE WE USE THE CORRECT NAME FOR THE WEASLEY'S SHOP, I'VE NAMED IT CORRECTLY WHERE I MOVED IT.***

room.name: Veritas Wizard Real Estate Office
room.desc: Despite its small size and cramped appearance, the office look stern and severe. Ancient, polished wood covers the floor, with a wide, red carpet crossing from the southern door towards a desk in the centre of the room. The lower halves of the walls are also covered in wood, with the upper parts a bright, blank, white colour. Hanging from the smooth, white ceiling is a single candelabrum, filled with pale-yellow candles. A few, comfortable armchairs are scattered across the office and an impressive, tall chair with scarlet cushions and arm holders is visible beyond the desk.

extradesc.desc: There are twelve soft, low, aquamarine armchairs, grouped in pairs on both sides of the red carpet around low, oak tables. The magazines and papers on the table tops are colourful, representing houses in various shapes and sizes, with large gardens surrounding them. Even the smallest of the advertized buildings looks like a palace, pictured with flowers and soft, friendly vines caressing its surface.

room.name: Merenda Cafe - Interior
room.desc: The interior of this building directly contrasts with the luminous outside terrace. The floors are a dark, emerald green, the stones translucent. Under the glossy surface, a pattern of chaotic, black swirls covers the floor. Square, terra-cotta coloured tables line the walls, surrounded by black, lattice-backed chairs with red-brown cushions. Along the north wall, a wood-glass display case holds baked goods. Behind, a series of small, polished, black cauldrons hang above small fires, containing dark-brown fluids. Golden plaques above them declare that their contents are diverse kinds of tea and coffee. Elegant, silver pitchers labeled "Cream" and "Sugar" stand atop the display case, along with an ornate, wooden cash register. A single, chestnut door stands to the south of the store.

extradesc.desc: The flaming handwriting gleams every now and again, spelling out the words: "Tap the cake gently and speak the name of two sorts of fruit you would like to have on it. These will appear in an elegant design, randomly chosen from the Meranda Five, the five hand-made Meranda designs." An added line reads in bright crimson: "CAUTION: Do NOT let witches or wizards not out of Hogwarts yet perform the necessary charm!"

Sets upon heavy sets of baked snacks with cheese, mushrooms, or sausages are stacked in neat rows upon a sheet of self-cleansing paper that prevents the wooden underside of the display from being grease-stained. Tea and coffee cookies, either round, or squared, soft or biscuit-hard, are amassed in a separate shelf, in large, round, porcelain plates. A glass panel prevents any of the heavy snack scents from damaging the perfection of the cookie aromas. A second section of the display is filled with larger cakes, from appetizing chocolate cakes to the "Bewitch-it-yourself" cakes, which are rather plain except for the liberal amount of cream on the edges. There is a small note beside these cakes.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Parlor
room.desc: This pub is quite dark, lit only by a few lanterns on the wall, emitting a fuzzy glow. The dark paneled walls look very aged, as if they have stood for centuries. Large, squarely-cut tables sit in the centre of the room, with long benches next to them. Light seems to avoid the corners of the room, making the smaller tables there near invisible. Along the north wall is a bar, with tall stools lining it. The area behind the bar is much brighter, showing off the many bottles of liquor lining the wall. Hanging from overhead racks are surprisingly clean mugs and wine glasses. To the north is a door marked, "Kitchen/Storage", to the west the door simply reads, "Alley", to the east is the entrance to the pub and to the south is a long dark hallway, lit by a few more grimey lanterns, emitting a fuzzy glow.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Lower Corridor
room.desc: Here the stark dark wood continues down the hallway from the main parlor. To the east and west are rectangle, romanesque doors of mahogany each with a piece of framed parchment reading, "Private Parlors - See Bar for Rental." The walls are covered in an off-white swirling plaster, slightly yellowed by the glow of the fuzzy lanterns mounted on them. The din of the main parlor can be heard to the north and to the south the staircase to the hotel rooms above.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Staircase
room.desc: The dark wood hallway ends here in the simple square staircase leading upwards. To the east is a room labled, "Staff Only - Do NOT Enter" and to the west is a door labled, "Southern Private Parlor - See Bar for Rental." To the north the hallway leads to the main parlor, Muggle London, and Diagon Alley.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Eastern Private Parlor
room.desc: This wooden private parlor is fairly roomy. It is longer in length then in width, and has the appearance of a wide corridor. The northern wall is lined with book shelves. Sitting in front of the large fireplace on the eastern wall is two green squash chairs and a blue sofa. Mounted above the fireplace is a painting of a goblin revolt, masses of goblins charging at a line of wizards casting spells to drive them back. Tall draped windows line the eastern wall, enchanted to show nothing but a beautiful country side landscape with rolling pastures. The realness of the enchanted windows is lessened some by the fact that you can hear the traffic of Muggle London outside.

roomecho.desc: A large bang goes off to the east, presumably a car backfiring.
Cars zoom past outside, honking and speeding up in the busy London traffic.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Western Private Parlor
SECOND DRAFT The Leaky Cauldron - Southern Private Parlor
room.desc: Off from the main hall, the southern, private parlour has its floor, ceiling, and walls covered in molasses-coloured wood. Two, high-backed chairs are parked in front of an imposing fireplace that stands halfway along the western wall. The hearth's dark-grey material only adds to the cheerlessness of the room. A featureless desk, of the same wood as the floor, blends into the northern wall with a straight-backed, wooden chair behind it. The only light brightening the dismal room comes from the fireplace and the two sconces bordering the door to the hallway. The only visible exit is the door to the east, which leads back to the hallway.

extradesc.desc: . These two chairs are of a faded leather stuck to the frame with dull, brass pins. The chairs, when sat in, are actually quite comfortable, as the padding seems to form around one's body.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Upper Hallway
room.desc: The simple wooden staircase leads up here, to a simple hallway. The walls are painted a plain white, the floors a stained cedar that creaks when you walk upon it. To the east and west are two hotel rooms each adorning a large lock. An ornate, curly, gold number one adorns the eastern door, and a simliar two on the western door. The hallway continuess off to the north.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Room 1 - Bedroom
room.desc: The room is very cozy, and seems more modern than the old wood and faded stone of the pub downstairs. The wallpaper is that of cartoonish green vines curling up and down the walls. Small purple painted monkeys jump from vine to vine in the day time eat bananas at lunch time and sleep in the night. A king size bed dominates the room, with cheery-colored wood and a thick fluffy mattress. On the eastern wall adjacent to the bed is a night table with a ornately carved lamp that has no plug, no oil, and no candle. A small folded piece of paper on the nightstand reads, "Clap to turn on." The faded glass windows to the east shows the London landscape, and the busy traffic on Charing Cross Road. A small bathroom is accessed by a door to the east and the hallway of the Leaky Cauldron is to the west.

roomecho.desc: A monkey awakes from his slumber and crawls up the wall.
A monkey nestles into a trunk split, using the branches as protection from falling during its slumber.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Entryway
room.desc: Ancient dark stone comprises the eastern arch to the Muggle world. Its grey colour has yellowed and the mortar is crumbling; however, the arch is still strong. In its frame is an even older arched door leading out to Muggle London. A ceramic umbrella-stand, with many cracks in it, is situated next to the door, filled with many ratty umbrellas for wizards to use while in the Muggle world. The din coming from the main pub is to the west, the dim lighting stretching over this entryway.

roomecho.desc: A stream of muggle cars run past the Leaky Cauldron outside on Charing Cross
A chair scrapes across the floor to the west and the sound of boots can be heard.
A group of chattering muggles walk past the Cauldron's door, their conversation about something called a "CD".

room.name: Sewer Under Zambrovski's Yard
room.desc: This brick-walled tunnel connects to a vertical shaft, not unlike a well. Embedded in the shaft's walls are discoloured, iron bars, textured with flaking, embossed crosses. These metallic rungs lead up through a circular hole, offering a glimpse of the sky. Every ten feet, ruddy flames flicker in soiled bubbles. Fixed to the wall, these sullied spheres spread their lurid glow into the pitch of the arched tunnel heading east, where the vacillating shadows merge with a deeper darkness.

extradesc.desc: A patina has formed upon the bars. The crosses, once crimson in colour, slough off the shafts like flecks of bloody snow.
extradesc.keywords: discoloured iron bars flaking embossed crosses ladder rungs

roomecho.desc: A moth flutters towards one of the red flames. A tongue of fire licks out through its orb and the charred insect falls.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: An ancient lantern, its iron skeleton thick with rust, hangs haphazardly from the eastern wall. It sheds a dim, greenish light into a deep, uneven hole, blasted in the delicate brick work to the west, and illuminates the wall surrounding it. Cloudy smudges of a gritty, soot-coloured substance are visible around the gash and smeared in random intervals down the grey, pockmarked wall. Underfoot, a creeping, light grey mist curls slowly around the tops of fallen, smashed bricks that are strewn in heaps across the treacherous trail. It continues to snake its way along the ground to the northeastern exit as though disturbed by something in the passageway that lies to the south.

extradesc.desc: The viscous substance seems to have originated from whatever blasted the cavity in the wall. It appears to have been smeared further along the wall by grappling fingertips.
Caught on one of the corners of a protruding brick, hangs a jagged scrap of dirty, yellow cloth.

roomecho.desc: An echo, sounding like a heavy footfall, bounces off the walls.

room.name: Beneath The Beastiary's Storeroom
room.desc: Stale water drips methodically from the arched ceiling and mixes with the perpetually-coiling, snake-like mist below. A brown-green liquid, exuding the foul stench of decaying matter, cascades through a stained, metal grate covering a narrow opening in the western wall. Further to the northeast, three, evenly-spaced, horizontal lines are etched deeply into the otherwise even surface of the concrete wall. An insignificant amount of sickly, greenish light glows from the passageway to the southwest. It glints eerily on the moist brickwork as the corridor bends and continues to the east. A small, wooden trapdoor in the ceiling provides access to the room above.

extradesc.desc: Just behind the metal lattice of the grate, years of debris and rotting refuse from the street has become trapped, creating a noxious, toxic soup that pours steadily into the passageway.
The three lines are carefully carved into the wall, like an arcane hieroglyph or territorial marking that claims possession of this space.

roomecho.desc: A low rumbling resounds from somewhere south.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: This chamber widens slightly as the tunnel curves around a bend. The single torch, fixed on the wall, does little more than cast irregular shadows around the corners. To the southwest, flickering, red light illuminates the passage. Tendrils of black mist drift along the floor of the eastern tunnel, groping hungrily along the uneven, stone floor. Between the spreading water stains and uncertain light, it is impossible to pinpoint the original colour of these brick walls. Currently, they are a mottled yellow-brown, with dark patches where noxious fluids have seeped between the bricks, trickling in widening streams towards the reeking puddles on the ground.

extradesc.desc: The inky ophidian-mist coils and twists around your legs. The vapor is so inundated it clings heavily, making it difficult to move.

roomecho.desc: A fine spray of fetid liquid bursts from a crumbling patch of mortar, ceasing as abruptly as it began. The stench of raw sewage hangs in the air.
The trickling sound of flowing water echoes off the curved walls, filling the space with liquid sound.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: Like rays of sunlight, three, pallid shafts stretch west, southeast, and northwest. The low ceiling is slowly crumbling from the fetid moisture seeping through it. Caked from years of dripping wax, green, everlasting candles cling to each walled fork of this trifurcated room. Their illumination causes the mouths of the tunnels to appear as silhouetted shapes, obscuring any visible clue to their contents or eventual destinations. A small pile of blackened bricks sits on the floor, shrouded in a damp, swirling mist.

extradesc.desc: The bricks are made of an unusually-brittle substance that matches none of the surrounding walls. The constantly-coiling mist has dampened the stones, causing their grey colour to appear black in places. Most of the bricks are smashed into large, fist-sized chunks and appear to have been hurriedly arranged into a small pile to mark one of the routes through the tunnels. Atop the pile sits a piece of wood.
The wood, pale brown in colour, appears to be half of a broken wand. It points northwest.

roomecho.desc: A faint tapping noise comes from the western tunnel.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: The narrow passageway curves heavily to one side, obscuring any view of what may lie beyond several feet. The low, brick ceiling and the stifling, oppressive air create a claustrophobic quality. The lack of ventilation creates a suffocating wall of humidity, leaving the tunnel's reddish brickwork damp to the touch. To the east, a couple of crumbling, dilapidated, brick steps lead to a solid wall, where bricks of a slightly-lighter shade shape what was once a doorway. The wooden, crouched ceiling is splintered and mouldy. The passageway continues to the southwest and northwest.

extradesc.desc: The defunct doorway is low, narrow, and clearly not meant for regular use. Some of the mismatched bricks, used to wall it off, are discoloured in patches, as though blasted by omnifarious spells. Small, shallow pockmarks show more evidence that someone has attempted, and failed, to gain access to whatever secrets are hidden behind the wall.

roomecho.desc: A rapid, tapping noise comes from just around the corner.

room.name: Behind Zambrovski's Pub
room.desc: This patio, at one time may have been attractive, but is currently in complete disrepair. Deteriorating slats of wood attempt to shape some form of demarcation; however, with boards missing, snapped in two, or worn thin from the weather and years, the remaining laths are too few to be called a fence. Small patches of grass grow from the hard ground; a few, frail morning glories endeavor to reach towards the distant sun. Flecks of pale, blue paint huddle beneath the dilapidated, wooden table and rickety bench. The sour smell of alcohol couples with the pungent, stench of urine creating a miasmic haze. Battered crates are stacked haphazardly, skirting a recess in the corner. The wooden door to the east leads back into the watering hole.

extradesc.desc: The crates are an amalgam of split boards, loose nails, and missing slats. Most of them hold varying, empty, liquor bottles. The boxes nearest the door are empty of everything save the odd, mildly-intoxicated spider.
A bottle teeters precariously. Though soiled and peeling, the label Apsides can barely be made out.

roomecho.desc: The sound of gushing water can be heard from below.
A stewed spider slips off a slat and sinks into the shadows.

room.name: The Beastiary's Storeroom
room.desc: This stone-floored storeroom smells strongly of musk and ammonia. A dim, smoky lantern hangs from the centre of the ceiling. Cramped shelves cover every available inch of wall space. The north-eastern shelves, facing the door, contain all manner of foods, bedding, and equipment for the care of magical beasts. The north-western shelves hold wire cages of all sizes. To the south-east are shelves holding aquariums and large glass bowls. A wooden trapdoor lies in the middle of the room.

extradesc.desc: Suspended from a thin section of rope, the lantern holds a single candle. Even at its brightest, the weak, guttering light barely travels to the corners of the room.

The shelves are made of solid, sturdy planks, fastened together with steel bracing. Above the north-eastern section, a scrawled sign reads, "Fur and Fangs", while the south-eastern twin bears the words, "Scales and Slime".

Thick, black wire cages line this whole section. Some are empty, save for a few feathers or bits of straw, while some hold living animals. Ominously, the doors of two cages on the bottom shelf have been torn open.

The glass facings of the aquariums lining this shelf all have an embedded, glowing series of runic markings on them. Within each transparent prison, either filled with water or lumps of plant matter, a living creature sits in silent darkness.

A thick series of iron deadbolts line all four sides of this trapdoor. The wooden surface is heavily marred by claw, tooth, and beak marks. A portion of the wood has been ripped clean off, leaving large talon-shaped scars behind. The aftermath leaves barely enough room for entities to slip through, that is, if they were able to stomach the waste and debris from all the room's occupants leaking through.

roomecho.desc: The tail of the nundu mounted over the door twitches.

room.name: Charing Cross Road - Outside The Leaky Cauldron
The Leaky Cauldron - Room 1 - Bathroom
room.desc: Room one's bathroom is fairly plain and ordinary. The white stone fixtures are faded and chipped here and there but are fairly functional. The simple sink to the north is chipped around the edges but still runs perfectly. The square-edged bath looks a bit dull and watermarked, but is relatively clean. A frosted glass window lies to the east, with large railroad spikes pounded through the frame and into the wall.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Room 2 - Bedroom
room.desc: This hotel room looks like a lost relic of a richer age. The crown molding is inlaid with gold foil, the mirror is gilded and the wallpaper shimmers like glossy silver. A canopy bed is draped with purple velvet and the blankets are faded white and feather-stuffed. The large stone fireplace opposite the bed looks big enough to hold a full dresser. Two giant, plush, leather chairs sit in front of the massive fireplace. Above the mantle are two crossed, golden cutlasses. A towering mahogany armoire rests against the eastern wall. A door set in the western wall presumably leads to the bathroom.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Room 2 - Bathroom
room.desc: This bathroom was obviously created to level in luxury with the lavish bedroom. The floor is one huge slab of white marble with no lines. Its surface is scattered with tan irregular streaks running diagonally across the stone. The walls are more breathtaking, enchanted to look like a tropical sea, waves rolling and crashing against themselves with the true sounds of the ocean echoing around. There appears to be no ceiling, only a perfect sky, puffy cumulus clouds rolling about an otherwise empty blue sky and the sun above lighting the room. At night in the real world, the ceiling reflects it and shows a spectacular full moon beaming a faint light over the bathroom. The bedroom of room two is to the east.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Upper Hallway
room.desc: The stained cedar hallway continues on here, stretching off to the north and with its end just to the south. Amidst the plain white walls on either side here are two doors, both with a golden metal number on it. To the east is room three, and to the west is room four. The hallway continues off to the north, and the stairway back to the Cauldron's pub is to the south.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley
room.desc: The pale cobblestone of Diagon Alley splinters off into a deteriorated back alley here. Bordered by walls and buildings, the path is in disrepair, not getting any of the attention given to the main way. The white brightness of the nearby, southeastern road is here replaced by different shades of grey, increasingly darker as the road advances to the north. A damp, unhealthy-looking, green plant stretches between the cobblestones, accumulating in low, spongy thickets at the feet of nearby buildings. A very short path pulls off towards the west into a dead end against a high wall. Painted onto the wall of the large, eastern building is a gigantic, faded advertisment, as though this alley was previously a main vein of commerce.

extradesc.desc: Faded onto the bricks of the eastern building is a large rectangle of brownish paint, which might once have been red, with towering, white letters reading, "STEPPENWOLF'S MAGIC CARPET CLEANERS - 174 Diagon Alley, London". Flying through loops and gaps of the letters is what might once have been a blue and purple carpet with golden tassels on its corners.

room.name: Twilfitt and Tatting's
room.desc: The hushed atmosphere of this room resembles that of a private club more than that of an ordinary clothing store. At the entrance to the south, a reception desk guards the shop from any riff-raff. A pewter plaque set into the front of the desk discreetly declares the establishment to be 'Twilfitt & Tatting's'. Samples of currently-available robes hanging in frames of dark, wooden mouldings take the place of artwork and proclaim the purpose of the elegant room. The bare floor is polished parquet, bordered by a sinuous pattern in a darker wood. The vaulted ceiling is covered in decorative plaster medallions that echo the supple twisting pattern in the floor. Matte-finished pewter lamps provide ample supplement to any natural light pouring in the plate glass shop-front. Four large alcoves branch off the main room, two to the west and two to the east. Each is equipped with a changing area, curtained off with heavy, emerald velvet on brushed pewter fittings; a comfortable sofa and a small, polished table.

extradesc.desc: This curved, tiger-oak desk is placed directly in front of the main door to Twilfitt & Tatting's. A graceful, flowing pattern of inlaid ebony twines around the edges, both vertical and horizontal. The broad top is bare, except for a spotless, emerald-green blotter and a silver pen-stand, complete with a silver-chased crystal inkwell.

Mounted inside rectangular frames made of elaborate mouldings, elegant robes decorate the walls. Most are subtle and sophisticated, relying on clean lines and rich materials for their impact. Women's clothing is displayed to the east; men's to the west, with the most formal of the garments hanging to either side of the front windows. The well-made and practical day robes drape with the unmistakable grace of linen. More formal outfits incorporate silk, brocade, and velvet. Most of the men's robes are black or deep shades of green and blue. The women's clothing is more vibrant, from the sophistication of a fitted black robe trimmed in blood-red, to an eye-catching sapphire-blue gown with black and silver trim.

The most formal evening attire is evidently intended as a set. The men's dress robes are impressive. The rich drape of black velvet displays mere hints of the emerald silk lining at wrists and throat, with buttons and piping in antique silver. The heavy nap of the velvet is sculpted around the cuffs, creating an understated pattern of black-on-black, Celtic knot-work. The women's evening gown is a brighter counterpoint in emerald velvet and black silk. The form-fitting velvet bodice reveals a hint of black silk along the sweetheart neckline. The flowing skirt is trimmed in black, with a touch of silver lace in strategic locations. The same knot-work motif found on the men's robe circles each sweeping, dagged sleeve, as well as the tiny, corseted waist.

roomecho.desc: A silver tea-service floats unobtrusively into an alcove, setting itself elegantly on the little table intended to receive it.
A saleswitch, impossibly tall and thin, flows across the floor, displaying the shop's wares - a flowing formal robe in black silk-velvet.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: A thick coat of green slime covers the arched, stone ceiling; viscous, syrupy globules drip with a reverberating echo into the sludge underfoot. Wispy, silver fingers of mist creep up the sides of the huge, grey stones constructing the walls. A constant, subtle draft brushes through from the western and northeastern passages, carrying with it the putrid scent of rot and decay. On the ground, glinting through the writhing mist, are the glass fragments of a smashed lantern. The remaining lantern is encrusted with years' of sewage, its feeble flame struggling against the dreary surroundings.

extradesc.desc: Though its framework is strong and weighty, rusty lantern's metal skeleton is disfigured where it has been ripped from the wall. In places, it is covered in patches of a black substance - residue from the magic used to remove it. Congealed blood around the base of the lantern suggests that it has had more uses than simply shielding light.

roomecho.desc: A sound of slow, repetitive scraping echoes from around a corner.

room.name: Gladrags Wizard Wear
room.desc: This large, spacy store is rectangular and neatly arranged. Racks on which robes of all colours are arranged in orderly rows in the center of the room. On the far wall is a shelf full of wizard hats, while on the west side of the store, mannequins modeling dress robes and cloaks stand. Mirrors stand against the east wall, and in the midst of them sits a cashier's clerk piled high with bundles of clothing. Both the walls and floor of the store are paneled with polished oak, and round lamps hang from the ceiling. Faint music plays in the background, its source unseen. The scent of new clothes contributes to give this shop a bright and modern atmosphere.

room.name: Lady Gemma's Fine Jewellery for the Mystical
room.desc: Soft, multi-coloured gleams dance across the entire surface of the room, coming from crystals and gems the size of a strong man's fist that slowly float across the ceiling. Their motion is smooth and has the unreal quality of shadows, their hues ascending or descending across colour scales. From their display cases, various pieces of jewellery catch and reflect the light clearly in rainbows of sparkles. Exotic and mystical items, from the strangest sapphire-silver anklet to the finest golden chain with a Vishnu-shaped figurine at the end, are displayed all around the room, in cases fixed in mid-air at various angles. The chamber seems endless, with the walls covered in mirrors reflecting the wavering glitters within. A reddish, mahogany door to the north leads back into Diagon Alley.

extradesc.desc: The display cases are made of mahogany, with glass tops. Inside, crimson cushions for silver and blue cushions for gold hold a most impressive, beautiful collection of necklaces, rings, bracelets, medallions, crowns, and anklets. Heavy, silver designs blaze with the breathtaking beauty of rubies, diamonds, or emeralds. The gems are so refined they seem a single Phoenix tear, fallen within the designated place the jeweller has chosen for it. Tiny, delicate, thin rings with a single stone or pendant lavishly gleam beside larger, diamond and emerald ones. There are medallions of any deity imaginable, all wonderfully sculpted into a single stone or gem, and necklaces in passionate or tame colours, but all perfectly executed. Anklets ranging from simple, silver designs to heavier, silver serpents with ruby eyes and outstretched Phoenixes, with plumages made of pure gems catch the eye. Lady crowns, made of millions of tiny diamonds, rest besides larger, golden-sapphire ones, fit for a king. There is also men's jewellery, made generally without stones but with intricate, breathtaking designs.

The door leading out into Diagon Alley is made of mahogany, its reddish-brown shade no less mystical than the soft light inside the shop. Gleaming, reddened lines show that the owners are up-to-date with their jinx, curse, and break-in protection.
Smooth and well polished, the wooden floor catches the light eflected by the gems and crystals.

Various gems and crystals, including moonstones, emeralds, rubies, jades, bloodstones, sapphires, and opals, dance across the ceiling, occasionally touching each other in soft, musical clinking. An enchanted light burns within them, reflected through the surface in whatever the colour the gem happens to be at that time. The flame throws mysterious, kaleidoscopic patterns across the polished, wooden floor.
As you look into the mirror, you see yourself staring back, as well as the light from the gems sparkling around you.

roomecho.desc: Sparkles float around the room as light refracts through the facets of the floating gems.
The gems shift colour slightly, casting beautiful lights and shadows around the room.
A young woman giggles excitedly as she gazes at the riches displayed in the cases.
A couple of customers wander into the shop, gazing at the jewellery in the display cases.
Hogwarts students slip into the store to gaze at the beautiful jewellery.

room.name: Quality Quidditch Supplies
room.desc: Quality Quidditch Supplies is jam-packed with varying items. The dark wooden floor has various racks of Quidditch robes sporting Wizarding team names. The parchment coloured walls are covered with pictures of famous Quidditch stars and matches. To the west is a waist-tall, dark, wooden block stretching to the north wall of the room. Behind it is a place for a clerk to stand and a wall filled with an assortment of brooms, from the old Shooting Star to the fabled Firebolt which sits in the display case. At the back of the store is a plain staircase leading upwards and to the south is the door back to Diagon Alley. To the north lies an alley.

room.name: Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes
room.desc: ****Book 6, Ch 6. Make sure street outside reflects this change of the shop now being here. (was in 5095, now here)**** Upon entering this shop, a small bell above the door chimes, then begins to speak, "Welcome to Weasley's Wizarding Wheezes, for all your jocular jibes, and jiggery-pokery!"

extradesc.desc: Above the door, fixed so to be struck upon opening, a small, golden bell hangs from a thread. The tongue inside is shaped, coincidentally, like a tongue. Around its rim, in slanted, bespoke script, are the words "VerBell Chimes - because words speak, and that's good enough for us".

room.name: Peltrude's Divination
room.desc: Dim, hazy fog completely encompasses this room. The floor is shrouded in a carpet of smoke, coiling up the walls in thin wisps. The sides of the shop are cluttered with hundreds of objects ranging from small crystal balls to large, stone basins. A huge, round, oak table sits in the centre of the room, a glass sphere placed in the middle. The enchanted ceiling mirrors a warped image of all beneath it. The door to the east is made of solid oak, with the notable addition of black satin drapes that end somewhere beneath the ground mist.

extradesc.desc: In the illusion above, sinister robed figures swish across the room. Dark hoods keep their faces in eerie darkness. The reflection shows the table as a large lion that sits in the middle of the room, calmly swishing its tail. The smoke that lines the floor is gone, replaced by a thick layer of boiling, bubbling blood.
extradesc.keywords: mirror ceiling up enchanted image warped

extradesc.desc: The tabletop is expertly carved to depict numerous wild cats pitted against an army of bears and snakes. Indented patterns of ancient origin line the circular edge. The legs of the table are whittled into tree-like figures with vines twisting downwards, each ending in the head of a lion.

The glass ball emits a gentle glow through its translucent surface. The origin of the internal light is a small sphere, surrounded by a boiling haze of purple cloud. The base of the sphere is made of polished brass. Worn and aged, the inscription has faded to a dulled, brown vestige.

roomecho.desc: 'The glass sphere on the table glows ominously.'

room.name: Player Shop
room.desc: This dusty, abandoned shop is awaiting purchase.

room.name: Dragon's Nest Inn
room.desc: The inn is lit with a fiery, glowing hearth. An insipid, woollen rug sparsely covers the oak flooring. A few tables are placed in the centre of the room, each holding a single candle. The southern corner is home to a large, rectangular bench fitted with plush, red cushions. Above the bench hangs a picture of a nesting dragon. The entire north-eastern wall is taken up by an oak counter, serving as a bar. Large, ebony shelves line the wall, holding bottles of differently-branded drinks, flickering with reflected light. Beside the bar, a spiralling staircase ascends up the side of the inn. A door positioned on the south-east of the room leads out into Knockturn Alley.

extradesc.desc: The rug is made from grey wool, its tarnished appearance suggesting over-usage and negligence. Being rather bland and forgotten, it lacks any particular form or a pattern. Beneath the rug, through large, ragged patches, a rustic, oak floor can be seen.
extradesc.keywords: rug insipid woollen carpet oak flooring down

extradesc.desc: A blue-scaled dragon poses nobly in its nest against the backdrop of a glowing sunset, its axe shaped head raised high. The sun bleeds its penultimate rays of streaming fire across a vast mountain range capped in snow. The dragon's muscular body is coated in rippling scales. Its front legs end in glistening talons, thrusting from the tips of the beast's long, thick fingers. Each wide, deep-blue wing holds a razor-sharp horn. The tail is long and thick; dozens of pointed spikes lined up in rows descend down the dragon's spine. Its light-grey, shimmering eyes scan the area around it, projecting an ice-cold blanket of destructive potential.

The rough, stone fireplace is coated in a blanket of black soot. Inside, flames weave in and out of each other, sliding across lumps of wood with a liquid elegance. The constantly-evolving dance breeds a majestic quality, as the light clings to the glowing logs, flickering furiously as particles of wood spark and crackle. A beautiful, curved archway passes over the mouth of the fireplace. The singed base is a thick slab made of welsh slate.
extradesc.keywords: light fiery glowing heart fire corner

roomecho.desc: The dragon in its painting snores quietly as small puffs of smoke vent from its nostrils.
The fire in the corner crackles quietly.

room.name: Abandoned Shop
room.desc: This long-forgotten room seems to have once been a shop. A deep carpet of dust and grime obscures the broken shelves and unidentifiable, rotting wares. Thin shafts of light manage to squeeze past the boarded up windows, highlighting the thick, musty air. Through the hazy miasma, one can make out a streak of foul slime leading behind the decaying counter. The door to the west is magically sealed - a contrast to the eastern exit, where the door hangs freely off its hinges.

extradesc.desc: Under closer scrutiny, the shelves seem to be filled with animal remains: skulls, jars of organs, a string of hands, and bowls of teeth. Each item has a small, iridescent seal bearing the words "Seal'd by Ministry, Dare not thy curious hand unleash".
Nailed shut and barricaded with heavy-looking planks, these blackened, aged windows are clearly unusable to air or light.

A colossal, basalt plateau once served as counter-top here. Now it is another well-worn eulogy to a miserable past. A glutinous trickle of a red and greenish-brown substance leads behind the counter, concealed from view.

Following the gruesome path of fluid, one is met with an even more horrific sight - the lower half of a human skeleton. The legs of this half-corpse are splayed, broken as though pulled backwards the wrong way through a hole. The spine is torn in two, a pile of ragged robes are all that remain of the upper body.
The front door to the shop has been enchanted to grow extensive, thorny barbs into the surrounding walls, sealing itself permanently.

roomecho.desc: A loud scraping of claws can be heard to the east, followed by a muted splash.
A putrid, overwhelming stench assails your senses.

room.name: Player Shop
room.desc: This dusty, abandoned shop is awaiting purchase.

room.name: Blunkett's Books and Scrolls
room.desc: This bookshop is pungent with the distinct odour of age-old parchment. A high, carved ceiling towers threateningly above, like an eagle watching its prey. Swirling patterns etched in iridescent silver blossom across it, throwing light on the small displays of various foreign parchments, scribes, and texts. On the north-eastern and south-western walls, two bookcases tower high into the air. Towards the back of the shop sits a large, oak counter, varnished to its finest presentation, behind which hangs a portrait of an old, bearded man. A large, spiral staircase twists downwards into a hollow cove. A sign is placed above it showing "Rarities" written in an italic script. The north-western wall of the shop is home to a large, dungeon-like door bristling with iron spikes.

exit.name: down
exit.description: The heavy stone steps spiral down to the rare books section.

exit.name: northwest
exit.description: The heavy oak door leads back out to Knockturn Alley.

extradesc.desc: Carved faces jut out from each corner of the ceiling. When not watching the people below, their attention turns to the eddying, gyrating tumulus. Thin, silver strands ebb and flow across the wooden beams, rendering effigies of mice, bats, small birds, and exploding flowers. The scene casts a soft, rippling light on the books underneath.
extradesc.keywords: ceiling up light carved eagle swirling patterns iridescent silver

extradesc.desc: The dark shade of this stained, oaken door fuses perfectly into the dungeon-like spikes set on the surface. Each sharp spike is tipped with a glistening point. The hinges are twisting dragon's heads cast from strong, durable iron.

The gigantic painting, which sits in a golden frame patterned with faded runes, and insignia, depicts an aged, haggard wizard. A long, grey beard falls down his soot-black robes to his waist. His wild, grey eyes stare out from the dark shadows marring his features. He leans upon a wooden staff, the other hand tucked into the robes around his chest.
extradesc.keywords: behind portrait old bearded man wizard painting golden

extradesc.desc: Sat neatly on the mirrored slab of the counter is a logbook, open and ready to be signed. The fine, hand-sewn binding glows with a subtle radiance. An inked, coiling, fire-breathing dragon borders each page. Sat atop the book rests a small, midnight-black quill. An elegant strip of silver runs down its fine, feathered taper. The tip of the quill holds a small amount of violet ink.
extradesc.keywords: counter back large oak varnished presentation

roomecho.desc: The wizard in the painting coughs gently.

room.name: Muddlestone's Malicious Monstrosities
room.desc: From the lustreless floor to the dead, metal walls, every surface in this warehouse is made of cobalt-blue steel. A crowd of rusty chains dangle from the ceiling; a dreary glow from the bottom link of each lights the room in monotonous grey. Scattered here and there, piles of broken antiques lie atop wooden crates. Small pieces of parchment hang along the side of each crate, denoting prices for the various items nestled within the mangled mess of brass. Towards the rear stand two ample cabinets, one on each side of the main counter. A number of broad shelves adorn the two adjacent walls, each shelf containing a single, magically-enchanted item. The obscure character of the shop suggests that the store name is a ruse meant to conceal its Dark Arts-centred nature.

extradesc.desc: Like hungry serpents, the glowing chains directly overhead grope towards the occupants of the room, shedding light upon their immediate surroundings.
extradesc.keywords: rusty chains ceiling up glow light

extradesc.desc: Among the heaps of brass and straw-filled crates, a few interesting fragments of antique objects can be seen; a huge crystal ball sits alone in one crate, another contains a curious-looking porcelain tea set, yet another holds the smashed wreckage of a grandfather clock.
extradesc.keywords: piles broken antiques wooden crates mangled mess brass

extradesc.desc: The steel shelves are bolted onto the wall. On each stands a single object accompanied by a small sign, "Please ask for assistance; wandering fingers won't get very far". The edge of each shelf looks worryingly razor-sharp.
extradesc.keywords: shelf walls broad shelves magically-enchanted items

extradesc.desc: A cracked orb, around a foot in diameter, sits in a halo of straw. Silver threads are etched in the surface in a series of erratic, maddening spirals. The translucent crystal sphere is filled with a deep-scarlet mist, undulating chaotically. When the smoke occasionally takes a clearer form, it is generally the form of a leering, winged skull.

An exquisite pot, two saucers, and six delicate-looking cups are causing havoc on an oval tray. With the cups attempting to kick each other off the tray, the saucers emitting thick gobbets of sickly-brown vapour coalescing into image of a cobra's head, and the teapot stomping up and down in the middle of the general chaos, it is difficult to distinguish the insignia on this visibly ancient set.

Through the chaos, one can just make out a silver and scarlet design. The insignia represents a coiled serpent, its head raised and poised to attack. Jagged, scarlet streaks across the belly of the beast look like the work of either a madman or a tattoo designer. The serpent moves its head sideways very slowly; its eyes opened slyly, forked tongue probing the air.

roomecho.desc: Something in one of the crates rattles noisily.

room.name: Artist's Studio
room.desc: The mephitic scent of strong chemicals hangs like a mist in this artist's spacious workshop. Adorning the visible sections of wall several previous works hang, lit by strange, golden lamps. The floorboards bear the crimson, viridian, and amber wounds of the painter's wrath and folly. Wide shelves line the walls, stacked high with pigments. A huge array of primed, blank canvases, painstakingly woven out of unicorn hair and spider webs, lie stacked in one corner. In the back, an enchanted section of wall shows shifting images of great landscapes, sombre streaks of sienna, and scenes of renowned wizard duelling grounds. A magnificent, cedar counter finds support from two stout, wooden A-frames. Pots of paintbrushes are placed, ready for use, beside large racks of palette knives, scalpels, pencils, and quills. Two voluminous tomes, bound in white leather, lie open on the counter. A stone stairwell pitches down into the main shop.

extradesc.desc: Bearing the gilt inscriptions, "Unstill Life: Capturing the Captivating", each massive book contains heavily-stained manuscripts on the curses and practises of unstill-life painting. Streaks of dirt and colour obscure several parts of the text, leaving dangerous guesswork for the unfortunate artist. One such passage reads: "Then, after boiling the substance down to a waxy sludge, crush one thorax of ... [text obscured]... Leaving overnight to ferment. Make sure you choose the young, green insects, as any variation would be most disasterous."
extradesc.keywords: voluminous tomes gilt inscriptions white leather books

extradesc.desc: The shelves sag under the burden of jars of deep-ochre shellac crystals, pearlescent slivers of malachite, and jars of powdered verdigris, lapis lazuli, and cinnibar. Great, brass dishes filled with lurid yellows and incandescent blues sit next to porcelain urns of oils and glass decanters of spirits. Some jars contain murky liquids with wriggling, writhing creatures inside. A large, glass globe on the top shelf holds hundreds of chattering purple insects, all clawing and scratching at the cork stopper above them.

A vast selection of well-used paintbrush pots stand to one side of the cedar counter. Brushes of moth-wing, veela-hair, and werewolf-bristle quiver with barely suppressed life where they stand. The brushes are arranged according to size and style; round, flat, filbert, and fan. Lying beside the pots is a well-worn, bamboo mahl stick, used by the painter to keep his hand steady.

The canvases are stacked in order of size ranging from tiny, palm-sized constructions, through elf-sized, to towering, troll-sized expanses of fabric and frame. Each primed surface catches the light in shimmering, ephemeral ripples, as if the material itself were alive.
This enchanted wall serves as a backdrop for the artist's needs, changing upon command to one of the thousands of vistas avaliable.

Hanging up on the scant patches of visable wall are works of the resident painter. Each masterpiece is a perfectly executed exercise in light and form, colour and expression. Ranging in styles from sullen, brooding, Carravagio-esque portraits to passionate, spontaneous landscapes reminiscent of the expressionists, the skills of the artisan working here are breathtaking.
Mournful, golden faces look down from the high walls, their eyes and mouths balefully illuminated by enchanted, blue naphtha flames held within.

Centuries of grime, blood, sweat, and paint are ground into every plank. The floor is a multi-coloured explosion of stains and spillages. Some deep, claw-shaped gouges mark where one wizard wanted himself painted in werewolf form. In one area, a dragon fancier's previous custom has scorched the floor black.
lamps paintings wall tomes

room.name: Jaded Jewels
room.desc: Every seam, lining, and edge in this room is perfectly accented in gleaming pearl. A plush, indigo carpet envelops the floor, running to the edge of the blond wood panelling embracing the walls. Cabernet-red candles float in mid-air, casting an ambience of refinement upon the surroundings. Solid-gold counters, armatures, and stands exhibit a dazzling array of jewellery: Chokers and chains of various lengths hang from the walls; dozens of necklaces and bracelets rest upon red velvet trays; an array of rings sits atop the counter upon sumptuous, crimson pillows. It is believed the Hope Diamond was cut here. The exit is to the north.

extradesc.desc: The diamond sparkles and dances in the light. The gold band glistens, making all who see it wish to touch its simple purity. Once this breathtaking treasure is placed upon a finger, a sharp spike plunges through the digit. Once through, the tip of the lance snaps ninety degrees, locking the ring in place.

The highly polished silver shines and the oval-shaped opals' ever-changing colours capture all eyes. After fifteen minutes of wear, the opals change into pearlescent, shimmering globules, seemingly solid and liquid simultaneously. Slowly boils, matching the opals in size and colour, begin to spread across the wearer's hand. The ring will not release its owner's finger despite all effort extended. The boils spread over the arm and eventually encompass the entire body. As the last boil erupts into existence, they all pop simultaneously. As the poisons ooze from the sores, the wearer's life ebbs from existence.

This thin bracelet is comprised of platinum weaved into an intricate braid. It dangles from the wrist, its dainty metal catching the light. The clasp is shaped as a snake's head, with emerald eyes, and a snake's tail. When fastened it becomes an ouroboros, imperceptibly reducing in length until it is too late for the wearer. No matter how hard it's tugged at, it will not stop its shrinking until the owner's hand is severed.

One gold chain, barely thicker than a thread, has a serpent's head as its fastener. The minute rubies, composing the snake's eyes, glint malevolently. Unfortunately for the wearer, this chain has the ability to unhook itself and slither down the wearer's belly. It then burrows a tiny hole into the person's navel. Once inside, it snakes its way to the heart, twisting itself around it, and squeezing it until its beat is stifled.

An ankh sits in the centre of this tiara with tiny stars and crescent moons surrounding it. Hundreds of flawless diamonds are used in this magnificent piece. The diamonds twinkle and shimmer as if the headdress was a chandelier casting its own luminosity. Platinum combs attached to the tiara affix it to a person's head. Once placed upon the head, the combs begin to grow. They slowly enter the skull and, tentacle-like, enclose the brain. Once snug, the tiara casts a permanent Befuddlement Charm leaving the wearer helpless to protect herself.

From the bulky to the delicate, chokers, beads, and chains of varying metals and precious stones hang from golden arms extending from the walls. One such chain is fashioned with a serpent's head, mouth agape, ready to bite.
One can choose to look at any number of bangles, beads, bracelets, necklaces, rings, chokers, or wristlets.

Bedecked with precious gems, glinting atop the gold counter, these necklaces, bangles, armbands, and bracelets nestle in deep, velvet-lined trays. A platinum bracelet, fabricated with a snake's head and tail, is among these wristlets. A single tiara is displayed alongside.
extradesc.keywords: dozens necklaces bracelets red velvet trays bangles

extradesc.desc: One of the more notable rings holds a princess cut diamond, while another bears six polished opals.

room.name: Zambrovski's Pub
room.desc: Two haggard, uneven doors to the east grant access to this unrefined, dishevelled drinkery. Poorly-lit lanterns hang precariously from the ceiling, providing a faint source of light. Vapors of putrescence weave through the stools, chairs, and tables. The aged bar clings to its last remnants of a mahogany-brown veneer. This tavern's shadowy corners are perfect for any who wish their presence unnoticed, if they are willing to endure the suffocating, heavy odour of years of smoke and alcohol concentrated in these areas. Lopsided portraits hang loosely against the two adjacent walls, showcasing some of the most notorious wizarding criminals in the world. A heavy, wooden door to the west leads to the outdoor courtyard.

extradesc.desc: Many of the portraits are nothing more than bits of aged parchment, stuck to the oak walls from a poorly cast Sticking Charm. Many of these illustrations are lopsided or peeling away. Some are worn thin, nothing more than brittle, illegible, yellow sheets scratched by black ink. A very old, but still visible poster, is of a man with a gaunt, haunted face and unkempt, dark hair. Scattered letters beneath the aging photograph read: 'Si u B la k'.

room.name: Hor Ryfic Hotel Lobby
room.desc: Titian globes form an udjat upon the mahogany ceiling, shedding minimal light on this vast lobby. The polished walls and floor superlatively match the wood overhead, reflecting the contents in a deep, ochre hue. A grandiose, periwinkle-tinged, crystal sphere glows eerily in the centre of the room. Plum-coloured, sumptuous sofas and plush, indigo armchairs are placed beside purpleheart coffee and end tables. Against one wall, a Caen stone fireplace houses crackling flames. Two ornately carved, marble caryatids stand either side of the fire, bearing a monolithic stone mantelpiece. Above the mantelpiece hangs a portrait of Horus Ryfic. To the northeast, on either side the heavy, revolving front door, diminutive umbrella stands, made of house-elf legs, hold two umbrellas each. The staff quarters lie to the southeast and the reception area is to the west.

extradesc.desc: A capacious, blue-hued, glass orb resides in the centre of the room. A glowing, orangeish-white light radiates from within the sphere. A shape appears to be dancing, flitting around gracefully, inside this translucent ball. Upon closer examination, one can see a lovely, lithe woman pirouetting and leaping. Her lissom form is captivating and wondrous. However, if one ventures too close or taps upon the glass, her entire being transforms. Her skin scales poisonous-green, her eyes slit, and her mouth elongates with enormous teeth dripping sheeny strands of saliva. She roars and lunges, trying to break through the glass. If one begs her pardon, she slowly metamorphoses back into the agile, willowy dancer.
extradesc.keywords: grandiose periwinkle-tinged periwinkle tinged tinge crystal sphere orb ball

extradesc.desc: Onyx frames this portrait of Horus Ryfic. His long, ebony hair cascades past his shoulders. Thin, dark eyebrows arch over his Promethean features. His platinum-coloured eyes glint like steel, taking in every movement beneath him, which seems fitting as it appears he feels everything is beneath him. His eyes narrow suspiciously at certain exchanges amongst the patrons as his mouth, set in a perpetual smirk, twitches.

The front door circumvolves leisurely, spinning like a whirligig's closing revolutions. Made of burnished pewter, this lumbering portal is too heavy to push along its course; instead, everyone who enters this auberge must follow the leaden, gyratory path. A Baphomet is engraved on each of the four panels comprising the door. Each Baphomet has a winged number nine etched upon their foreheads.

room.name: Back Alley of the Leaky Cauldron
room.desc: The small alley in the back of the queer pub, The Leaky Cauldron is a scrubby alleyway, covered in graffiti, some in alphabets nothing like anything on Earth. Random waste floats around the tan stone, newspapers, bits of rubbish, old leaves and other small pieces of garbage. There is really nothing to see here, unless you enjoy watching the rubbish swirl about. The alley turns off to the north, and the Leaky Cauldron is to the south.

room.name: Back Alley of the Leaky Cauldron
room.desc: Here the little alley ends abruptly in a towering wall of smooth stone. On the east side you see nothing but bricks and graffiti. The graffiti reads things like, "Murray rules!", "Jim and Francine 4Ever" and other random messages. To the west there is a small, narrow staircase leading down to a boarded up door, presumably to the basement of some condemnded basement to the west.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind Suchard's Shoes
room.desc: The building to the south has a small green door beset in the wall, adorned with the two letters, "SS". Next to the door is a large stack of worn leather and laces. A spindly, wooden staircase leads up to the roof of Suchard's Shoes, it being perfectly flat. The alley seems to stretch far to the west, and turns a bend to the east.

room.name: Diagon Alley - At the top of the stairs
room.desc: The stairway creaks as you walk on it, it seems very old and dusty. To the south you can clearly see the flat gray roof of Quality Quidditch Supplies. Below the alley stretches out east and west, running past all the shops of Diagon Alley. From this higher vantage point, you can see Muggle London stretch all around you, the Thames cutting through the city and the huge London Eye.

room.name: Stairwell
room.desc: This tall, square room is cosily lit by oil lamps mounted on the walls. Walls, floor, and ceiling alike are constructed of rough planks, sloppily painted a dingy, creamy colour. The floor holds a wooden trapdoor, equipped with a handle. To the north, a few, rickety, wooden steps lead into a more luminous open area. Thick mats of cobwebs fill the corners and stream from the stair treads.

extradesc.desc: Stubs of branches still protrude here and there from the wooden steps, smudged in a way that suggests they sometimes serve as handholds. The wedge-shaped steps are the same, rough planks as the walls, worn smooth and thin in the centre by the tread by years of feet. The entire assembly has been given a thick coat of brown paint. In some places, paint appears to be the only thing holding the stairs in place. There is no handrail, but dirty handprints on the cream walls reveal another way of steadying a climber.

roomecho.desc: A fly buzzes lazy circles around the top of the stairs.
A dusty grey spider pops out from a thick layer of cobwebs. It looks around, and then delves back behind the fluffy webs.

room.name: Beneath Blunkett's Rare Books Cellar
room.desc: The deafening sound of fiercely gushing water fills this cavernous, rectangular space. A high ceiling, constructed in a delicate grid of small, red bricks, arches over a narrow conduit. A constant flow of waste runs towards the northwest where a dark, narrow tunnel leads further into the sewers. On the southern wall the opening of a large pipe, covered with a grate, spews brown water in an elegant cascade to the channel below. In the southeastern corner crumbling, brick steps and a thin, rusted handrail, loosely attached to the wall, lead upwards. On either wall, in small, box-like alcoves, torches burn furiously with a pale green flame, casting twisted, erratically flickering shadows over the walls.

extradesc.desc: The grate covering the pipe is stained and rusty yet appears to be firmly attached to the wall. Behind the grid, sludge and debris has been caught. A dead rat lies in the flow of water, its slightly decomposing body pressed up against the metal bars. The smell coming from the the fetid detritus is repulsive.

roomecho.desc: The repetitive thump of some kind of machinery echoes from the northern tunnel.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Behind Quality Quidditch Supplies
room.desc: The crummy little alley runs behind Quality Quidditch Supplies here. In the distance to the east a curve can be seen in the alley, turning to the southeast.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind Scribbulus Everchanging Inks
room.desc: Here the back alley is littered with almost as much paper as the store to the west, Flourish & Blott's, and added to that are a slew of bent feathers, ink bottles and pools of inks of many colors. There is no trash container, it seems the rubbish is just thrown out the back door, assuming that someone will take care of it with a quick Scourgify, but it appears as though no one has.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind Flourish & Blott's
room.desc: Here the alleyway is behind the book store, Flourish & Blott's, clearly identifiable not only by the sign on the back of the building, but by the near endless supply of trashed books, paper and bindings behind the store. To the east and west the alleyway continues, and to the south is a door into Flourish & Blott's.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind Madam Malkins
room.desc: The milled alleyway continues here, behind more shops. To the southeast, a wooden door set in an old building has a curly sign next to the door reading, "Madam Malkins - Please Use Main Entrance, Around Alley." Directly to the south, a metal, green door has a sign that has various animals spelling out the words, "Magical Menagerie, EXIT Only." To the north stands a condemned building, long past its prime. To call it a building is even much; it is more of a rambled, wooden shack that appears to have once held a shop. A metal sign hangs from one of two, parallel-hanging chains, now horribly rusted. The path continues to the east and west, dusty and dirty.

roomecho.desc: The undeniable sound of squeaks emerges from the shop to the north, accompanied by fierce scratching.
A howling wind makes the crumbling shack to north cry in pain.

room.name: Narrow staircase in the alley of The Leaky Cauldron
room.desc: The pavement stairs lead down to a small square of ground next to a door boarded up with cedar. The red spraypaint on the door reads, "CONDEMNED DO NOT ENTER." A thick padlock loops through two simple metal arches on the door and its frame making it quite secure. It seems the only way out of here is going back up the stairs.

room.name: Inside the Condemned Building
room.desc: This small cramped room is only big enough for two people to stand in. There is no lights from any direction except the light beams filtering in around the door's edges.

roomecho.desc: You hear water dripping onto stone.

room.name: Condemned Building - Pitch Black Corridor
room.desc: The cramped hallway is still pitch black with no lights. The wall to the east is blocked off, but to the west, a dark opening opens up.

room.name: Condemned Building - Pitch Black Corridor
room.desc: The pitch black corridor continues on here, now reaching a large door with yet another huge padlock. The door is old, dusty and painted pitch black. To the east and west black stone constricts the passageway.
room.flags: dark indoors no_recall antimagic light nofly

room.name: Condemned Building - Pitch Black Corridor
room.desc: The cramped hallway is still pitch black with no lights. The walls to the west and east are blocked off with stone.

room.name: Inside the Condemned Building
room.desc: This small cramped room is only big enough for two people to stand in. There is no lights from any direction except the light beams filtering in around the door's edges.

room.name: Condemned Building - The Keen Magpie
room.desc: This seems the most oddly placed room imaginable. After the pitch black tunnel is a stone-walled pub. A sign above the cold stone bar reads, "The Keen Magpie" and has a picture of a black bird with a gold ring in its beak. Square wooden stools line the square bar, making it seem very uncomfortable, cold and utilitarian. The rest of the room has more comfy looking furniture, mismatched chairs and tables fill the room, making it look very unprofessional. A large fireplace on the south wall seems to give the room its heat, much warmer than that of the tunnel to the east. A door to the north reads, "STAFF ONLY - RESTRICTED ACCESS" and is guarded by a massive, unhappy looking man.

room.name: Player Shop
room.desc: This dusty, abandoned shop is awaiting purchase.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: The crumbling concrete floor, mostly obscured by swirling fog, is dipped, sloping away from the low passageways and in to a high-ceilinged, narrow space. Two eternally burning torches are hooked into place along the deteriorated brick of the eastern wall. The almost pure white light they emit shines directly on to the wall opposite revealing a large number of solid-looking hooks embedded into the wall at seemingly random points. Heavy, rusted chains of different lengths hang from a few of the hooks which, combined with the flickering of the dim light, gives the impression that the wall is dripping. The pathway slopes upwards slightly at either end as the tunnel continues to the west and the southeast.

extradesc.desc: The chains are sturdy-looking and heavy. Around the hooks they are attached to, rust has scraped away suggesting that they have been used recently. From the furthest chain hangs a stained, ancient manacle with traces fo caked blood around its rim.

roomecho.desc: The sudden, acrid scent of rot and decay penetrates the air.

room.name: Beneath Sweet Vengeance Back Room
room.desc: A multicoloured miasma fills the air of this round, underground chamber, drifting in slow spirals from the round, metal trapdoor high above. The aromas change with the tinted fog, shifting unpredictably from violets, to rotting meat, to overcooked green beans. The flaking brickwork that forms the walls is covered in an assortment of stains: some are fresh, others, old. Planted in the centre of the floor is a battered, iron pole, as thick as a man's arm. Thumb-thick bars sprout from opposites sides of the pole, forming a crude ladder that ends just below the trapdoor in the ceiling. Puddles of slick, malodorous goop have formed at the low points of the unfinished stone floor. A single, flickering torch is fastened above the entrance to a corridor leading northeast.

extradesc.desc: Though the wood is beginning to rot from the unrelenting dampness, it still remains solid, strong, and intact.

roomecho.desc: A gobbet of purplish gel oozes under the trapdoor high above, splattering on the ladder-rungs as it falls.
A wave of greenish smoke shrouds the room in the odour of spoiled kelp.

room.name: Knockturn Alley Sewers
room.desc: The misty air is overwhelmed by a foul stench of excrements and decay as these sewers travel underneath Knockturn Alley's maze-like structure. The walls are made of solid stone, breeding a lingering, never-ceasing darkness and rancid stench. Pale lamp-lights, placed randomly across the thick, tunnel-like walls, allow a faded glow to shine through, without which the surroundings would be invisible. The floor is the same as the walls, wet stone streaked with dirt. Lights glimmer east and southwest, struggling to cut through the tenebrous darkness. Their strongest rays break against the marked, dank stone.

extradesc.desc: Once black, the continual wear on these befouled lamps has made them a light grey.

roomecho.desc: The sound of scurrying rats echoes through the passage.

room.name: Sweet Vengeance Back Room
room.desc: This stone-floored room smells of a hundred different potions and poisons, some sweet, some repellant. The overall effect is a nauseating aroma, reminiscent of lilacs, chlorine, and fermenting cabbage. In the centre of the northwest wall, a heavy, black curtain separates this room from the public room of the shop. Along with a workbench, there are cauldrons of various sizes and materials. Some cauldrons, stored on high shelves and marked with dates, hold brews that are aging or stewing. Others, bubbling sluggishly on the work surface itself, hold brews in progress. The flickering flames beneath them serve as the primary source of light. The rest of the room is given over to shelving. Hundreds of tiny, tidily-labelled bottles occupy fully half of this chamber. Other shelves contain ingredients, with both standard magical attributes. A rack of aquariums inhabits one corner. Mounted on the wall next to the door is a small, red box with a glass front. A round, metal piece is centred upon the floor.

extradesc.desc: This workbench, topped with a slab of smooth marble, is equipped for brewing potions and poisons of all types. A wooden cutting board holds a heap of chopped fluxweed. A stone mortar sits in the centre of the bench, the pestle resting alongside. A variety of knives and stirring implements are ranged neatly in racks below the work surface. A tiny set of golden scales teeter gently from side to side. Propped against the wall at the back of the bench is a sign printed in block letters.

This notice has been hand lettered in black ink on stiff card. The heading reads 'Remember Workplace Safety'. Beneath it are three lines in smaller print. '1. Use bubble-head charm at all times. 2. Do not forget dragonhide gloves. 3. When in doubt, Apparate out. ' At the bottom of the card someone has added in violet ink '4. Don't mess up, or the boss will use you for a test subject. '
