Stenciled onto the front of this wall-mounted box are the words 'In Case of Emergency, Break Glass'. Inside, the dark, knobby outline of a beozar is visible.

Most of these glass tanks contain sleepy-looking snakes. One, mesh-topped aquarium is filled with agitated, flapping doxies. One contains a fat toad that changes colour every few seconds, cycling from sickly yellow, to bilious orange, to slime green, and back again. Pudgy, purple fish, bristling with spines, swim in another.
Looking down at this circular iron disc, one can make out glutinous, sinking speculations of sump. The grime slips, drips, and slides away, though never seems any cleaner.

room.name: Dragon's Nest Inn Landing
room.desc: The narrow landing is constructed of decrepit, age-old oak. Small alcoves in the walls hold forever-burning candles, illuminating a carved, thorn-like pattern covering the surface of the wood. The senile, crooked floorboards lead to the north-east and south-west, each terminating in a single, sturdy door. A rickety stairway leads down to the bar.

extradesc.desc: Inscribed into the surface of the wooden walls are a series of loops and twisted knots, every inch covered in sharp, protruding thorns.

Throwing light out over the landing, several gruesome-looking candles sit ensconced in small niches along the wall. Each waxy stump burns beneath a hovering, incandescent eye. As the eye blinks, a tear of wax is shed onto the stem of the candle, eternally prolonging its existence.

The solid, black doors at each end of the corridor have a Greek letter painted on them. Daubed upon the north-eastern door is a large, blood-red 'alpha' symbol, while the south-western door opposite bears a sickly, green mark of 'omega'.

roomecho.desc: The landing floor creaks lightly.
Soft flutters of candlelight dance shadows across the landing.

room.name: Guest Room Omega
room.desc: This dingy chamber is cloaked in a charcoal gloom and an acute stench of wet, rotten wood. Though the ambience is dark and intimidating, the lavish furniture appears in almost immaculate condition. A large, four-poster bed boasting delicate, grape-coloured drapes stands against the south-western wall. A small table sits beside the bed. Across the room, on the north-eastern wall, is a large, oak dresser, carved with peculiar insignia and patterns. The walls are a murky maroon; faded streaks across various sections indicate where pictures once hung. A dark-grey woollen rug, its surface slightly blemished but not worn, covers much the floor. Chunks of wood have come off the floorboards at the exposed sides of the room. A solid-looking door lies to the north-east.

extradesc.desc: The dresser is made of ancient, dark-brown oak, with etchings framing its large doors. On closer inspection, these twists and twirls would appear elegant, were it not for rusty traces along their golden surfaces. At each corner of both doors there is a coin-like circle, framing the stylised image of a dragon with outstretched wings. The wings too, are stained rust-red.
extradesc.keywords: insignia oak dresser carved carvings north-eastern peculiar patterns

roomecho.desc: A gentle sobbing can be heard from above.

room.name: Guest Room Alpha
room.desc: This spacious, shabby bedchamber is swamped with the stench of rotting wood. The peeling, greyish-yellow wallpaper is covered with dampness and mould. The chipped floorboards are warped and dotted with sharp, protruding nails. The corners of the room each hold a burning torch, illuminating the room. On the north-western wall, a small, circular window faces out over the back of the inn. Thick, cobalt-stained bars are fixed to the outside frame, leaving only a few thin slits to peer out of. Two grungy, twin-sized beds are sheltered by brown, moth-eaten quilts. Across the room is a painting caged in ebony. A broad, ash dresser is blanketed in a thin layer of dust. A sturdy door stands to the southwest, leading out to the landing.

extradesc.desc: Through the bars, the window looks down on the yard behind the Inn.

The painting is of a calm, lush meadow beneath a distant mountain. Formations of birds flit through the scene, the hazy light flickering off their wings. In the distance, a grey shadow passes over the snowy peak. Suddenly, a great arc of forked lightning cracks the mountain's surface, sending a slow carpet of dirt and rock shearing down the mountainside. A bronze inscription beneath the painting reads: "The Peaceful Doom of Zachariah Johansen".

roomecho.desc: The drawers in the dresser rapidly slam open then shut, ceasing as abruptly as they started.

room.name: Knockturn Alley
room.desc: This narrow, cobblestone street, running north and south, is shadowed by the overhanging buildings that tower on both sides. Footing is treacherous in the gloom, as the blocks forming the surface are uneven and broken in places. A malodorous, unidentifiable lump lies in the gutter, backing a trickle of tainted water into a murky puddle. The building to the west presents a blank, brick wall with a protruding second story where curtains flutter at a narrow window. The ramshackle building to the east, hunkered down between its taller neighbours; is a stout, grey, stone edifice amidst the cluster of brick and wood buildings. The sign above the eastern, reinforced, wooden door declares it to be an apothecary's shop. The point is rammed home by the accompanying decorative item: a glass globe filled with toads' eyes floating in greenish fluid.

roomecho.desc: The stinking lump in the gutter stirs, releasing a small flood of dark fluid from the puddle behind it.
The floating toads' eyes suddenly orient themselves in the same direction, clustering to one side of their globe. Curiosity apparently satisfied, they return to their random drifting.

room.name: Hor Ryfic Hotel's Reception Area
room.desc: A highly polished reception desk dominates the western wall of this mahogany-covered room. An ochroid runner reclines before the antique desk. Overhead, small, elliptical orbs emit a faint light from the fairies trapped inside. On the southern wall, a green-slate fireplace allows a fierce blaze to spread stifling, searing heat throughout the room. Lavish, midnight blue armchairs are set in a semi-circle around a rosewood coffee table. A collection of magazines are scattered upon the table. The exits lead east to the lobby, or upstairs to the guest rooms.

extradesc.desc: Made of crystal, these petite, oval-shaped spheres hold minute fairies inside. The various fairies are in differing states of frustration or despair. A few bang their fists on their transparent cages. Others are kicking the glass as hard as they can. Some have resigned to their fate and are lounging about, relaxing themselves to see what destiny has wrought. Two fairies, male and female, are facing each other. They have a single hand upon the glass, reaching across the ocean of space separating them.

Runes are etched along the rim of this aged desk. Each leg of the desk ends with a carved dragon's head. A brass bell sits atop the reception desk to summon the keeper of the keys. A large, red, leather-bound book has a date affixed to the top of each page. The pages are lined with the titles: "Name" and "Room Number". However, all the lines appear blank. The ibis quill scrawls in indiscernible ink to ensure the anonymity of each guest.

The first magazine, titled "Dragon Baiting: the new found craze sweeping the nation for the action-packed daredevil". The second publication is labeled "A Muggling We Go: short stories and poems about humiliating, afflicting, and vanquishing Muggles". The third periodical bears the moniker "Aphotic Music: a magazine for the Wizarding music scene for those who are tired of the pop, claptrap on the WWN".

room.name: House-elf Quarters
room.desc: Claustrophobic is an understatement for this room; closets are known to be more commodious. In addition to the stairs leading up, three wee beds, comprised of no more than plywood frames topped with a motley-coloured pile of spotless, varying sized rags, are stacked one on top of the other and engulf the space. Though this area is immaculate, it is in disrepair; the pus-yellow paint is peeling from the walls, floor, and ceiling. The only adornment in the room is a house-elf's head, mounted on a wall, with the words: "Do You Want This To Happen To You?" The door, its wood worn, is to the northwest.

extradesc.desc: The bulbous eyes are glassed over, yet still manage to portray a trace of fear in them. Its large, flappy ears are scarred and possess a few scorch marks.

A rainbow of colours cover these plywood slabs. The rags are an assortment of cloths, most appearing to be old, ripped sheets, tablecloths, and towels. They add only a modicum of comfort on these impoverished surroundings.

room.name: Hotel Stairwell
room.desc: The stairs are comprised of alternating wooden steps of cherry and oak. Threads of copper run along both sides of this stairwell, ending in a swirl upon each landing. Light, reflecting off the burnished, ebony walls, is cast from the sun rising in a painting. This work of art hangs opposite another canvas adorned with lurid colours. This gaudy picture is girdled in black, wrought iron twisted into a tight, yet bulky braid. The copper ceiling is pressed into an intricate fleur-de-lis pattern. To the east are guest rooms, while this flight of steps will take one up another floor or down to the reception area.

extradesc.desc: The sun, radiating light upon all around it, is rising in this relatively placid scene. The trees are amply leafed, the flowers blossoming and courting buzzing bees, and the birds are singing a lovely tune. If it weren't for the vampire shielding his face and screaming from the burning sun, one would want to picnic here.
extradesc.keywords: light sun rising painting work art

extradesc.desc: Against a neon-blue sky, three figures in soot-black, hooded robes stand laughing at a kneeling Muggle couple. The man, covered with a labyrinth of gashes across his face and arms, holds a protective stance over the woman, herself sporting a slit lip seeping cerise cruor upon her pink dress. Akin to macabre Christmas decor, glutinous, scarlet blood is splattered thickly upon the vibrant-green grass. The ominous figures cackle as one points his wand at the pair, eclipsing the scene with a jet of ruby-red light.
extradesc.keywords: canvas adorned lurid colours gaudy picture black wrought iron

roomecho.desc: A piercing shriek rents the air.

room.name: Hotel landing
room.desc: The floor of the landing is covered with sumptuous, eggplant-coloured carpeting with the symbol of the Witch's Ladder running down the length of the walls on both the north and south sides. Mahogany panelling covers the walls with wrought-iron, talon-shaped brackets wrapped around black candles. The flickering light casts long dark shadows across the landing. The two paintings hanging on the north side of the landing keep watch on the four doors to the east, south-east, south, and south-west. The staircase lies to the west.

extradesc.desc: The two portraits are of Vel Blackheart and Missy Fortune. Look closer if one wishes to see these paintings.

Hearts of Black Hills gold surround the portrait of Vel Blackheart. He has chestnut-coloured hair with a matching Vandyke upon his flawless face. His cinnamon-coloured eyes crinkle at the corners as his blood-red lips curve into a smile. Though he's smiling, his eyes hold a severity underneath, making it hard to veil the smug demeanour emanating from the portrait.

Wearing a royal blue, velvet robe, Missy Fortune's golden, wavy locks slink down her shoulders like thick snakes. Her pale eyebrows are perpetually raised above her frosty blue eyes, as though she regards all around her with disdain. Solid gold leaves of nightshade frame this portrait.

room.name: Staff Area Landing
room.desc: This landing is honeyed by the oaken floors, stairs leading down, ceiling, and panelling upon the wall. Framed in mahogany, with teeny, dancing house-elves etched into it, a painting spans the length of the northern wall. A warped melody emanates from it. Extending across the southern wall, a second canvas has framed in mahogany. Engraved in the wood are musical notes, spinning around one another. A mahogany door to the east grants one access to the manager's quarters while the mahogany door to the west allows entry into the kitchen. Placed on either side of the doors are house-elf heads shedding light upon all beneath them.

extradesc.desc: This work of art depicts a wizard with five house-elves. The wizard's jet-black hair is swept into a ponytail and he is wearing flowing robes that swirl with variegations of red- crimson, scarlet, ruby, magenta, and claret eddy and morph into one another. The five house-elves are physically similar, minimal differences in height, the extent their eyes bulge, the width of their ears, and the shade of their green skin. Each house-elf has a piece of kitchen paraphernalia- a cornucopia of pots and pans. The wizard is holding his wand like a conductor's baton, directing the house-elves. With each point of his wand, the chosen elf bangs the pan upon its head and emits a squeal. From these thunks on the head, and subsequent yelps, a macabre song emerges.

A witch, with long, auburn hair pulled into a plait, wears fluid robes of motley blacks- charcoal, obsidian, onyx, ebony, and raven whirl and transmogrify into each other. There a five house-elves, all mirror images of each other since they are quintuplets. The five are moving in synchronization- undulating their hips and moving their hands and feet in perfect unison to the refrain issued from across the room. The witch blasts the house-elves with little streams of blue light issuing from her wand, demanding that they dance more harmoniously. She laughs at the fear marring their tiny faces.
The house-elves' heads are mounted on oak plates. Their mouths are open, their tongues hanging out. A green flame burns in each mouth of the anchored heads, casting an eerie pallor across the room.

roomecho.desc: The man and woman from the paintings look at one another and smile perversely.

room.name: Manager's Room
room.desc: Dark, rich, assorted browns embrace this room. Plush, chocolate-brown carpet covers the floor with matching tiles on the walls and ceiling. The stout, four-poster, mahogany bed accommodates velvet, cinnamon-coloured bedclothes. A sheer, coffee-coloured canopy is fitted for the bed. The only splash of colour resides in a book and a small table. Partnered with the table is a sumptuous, brown, leather chair. A small, chestnut-coloured, stone fireplace dwells within one wall. Hanging on the wall is a portrait. To the west lies the mahogany door leading to the hallway.

extradesc.desc: This small, burnt sienna table allows small items to rest comfortably, such as the manager's favourite book, "Laughable Lies: Myths Muggles Perpetuate about Wizardry and Its Practitioners".

A wizened, pale woman, with long, braided, grey hair, has laughing, silver eyes. The crow's feet around her eyes are etched deeply, a tributary running from her eyes to her hair line. Her ancient, colourless lips, stretched into a thin smile, match her robes- antiquated and hoary with outdated, Queen Anne's lace ruffles. Though she resembles more a wisp of smoke than an actual human, she still emanates a sense of authority.

room.name: Staff Kitchen
room.desc: The kitchen is vast with vaulted ceilings and spotless, sparkling, silver utensils and copper pots hanging from the stone walls. An immense, brick fireplace is located upon the one end and several massive ovens, powered by fire, are set along another wall. The rest of the wall space houses stone counters and sinks. Spigots furnish fresh water and cause damp air to blanket the room. Upon the flagstone floor sit enormous bronze, copper, and pewter cauldrons of all sizes. Mismatched pieces of crockery, pans, and cutlery are scattered throughout the room or piecemealed across the tables. The pantries are full of delicious sundries. Enormous freezers possess slabs of meat and other savory items. Cupboards display the fine sets china, gold plates and utensils, and silver tea services polished to a high sheen. The exit is through the door to the east.

roomecho.desc: A pot falls from its perch and crashes deafeningly.

room.name: Warm Tomorrow
room.desc: The room is warm in both calefaction and ambiance; the aroma of roasted chestnuts lingers in the room. The walls and ceiling are covered in burnt sienna tiles. The alder, hardwood floor is adorned with a thick, indigo rug. A blue slate fireplace, along the southern wall, hosts a crackling fire. A Beachwood frame houses the bed and snowy-white sheets, canopy, and downy duvet. A cerulean and cream striped, cushy chair keeps company with an ivory side table. The exit is through the alder door to the north.

extradesc.desc: Etched into the stone is, simply, the word "Tomorrow".
Upon the table sits a book bound in dark blue leather. It's entitled "Tomorrow is the Day After Today: Memoir of a Blue Life".

room.name: The Safe Room
room.desc: The enchanted ceiling depicts perpetual nightfall, an occasional silver streak of a falling star slashing across the dusky colour. Beryl-green satin drapes the walls; they shimmer when touched by the light from the silver flames floating in each of the four corners of the room. Lush, emerald-green carpet is the platform for a brushed-silver, bed frame. A solid-silver safe, with an intricate lock, inhabits the corner. Etched upon the door are narrowed eyes that follow every movement in the room. To the west lies a door leading to the hallway.

extradesc.desc: A range of charcoal hues colour the high, arched ceiling. Intermittently, slicing through the inky darkness, is the hoary dash of a falling star.
extradesc.keywords: ceiling enchanted nightfall streak star falling

extradesc.desc: Burnished silver frames this thick, feather tick. The luxurious bedclothes are emerald-green velvet, embroidered along the edges with silver stars.

The intricate, silver lock resembles two bony hands with long, sharp talons. The talons are able to be manipulated, a complex puzzle of moving each talon in a certain pattern to open the safe. The eyes scrutinize each tic of the elongated nails, waiting for a mistake, which triggers the claw-like hands to seize the perpetrator.

room.name: Hotel Stairwell
room.desc: Composed of interchanging, wooden, cherry and oak stairs, the steps are embossed with copper lines stretching the length of the stairwell. They end with a spiral upon each landing. Glossy, ebony walls glisten from the light spread by the full-moon in the painting suspended upon it. This work of art hangs opposite a framed magazine. The facade of the Hor Ryfic Hotel is emblazoned on the publication's cover. A detailed, double quatrefoil pattern is pressed into the copper ceiling. The entertainment areas are to the east and the stairs lead down.

extradesc.desc: This painting resembles a bruise, a collection of blacks and blues. A white orb, shedding light, is hanging in its full cycle in the sky. The firmament ranges from azure, indigo, navy, royal, charcoal, dusky, sable, to inky. Beneath the moon lies dark grounds with black, shaded trees. A werewolf is howling; lustrous strands of saliva dribbling from his maw.
extradesc.keywords: full-moon full moon painting work art

extradesc.desc: The magazine's title is, "The Pure Luxury of Wizards". The face of the Hor Ryfic Hotel is captured on the front of this periodical. Underneath it is the caption, "For those who still care about purity, these accommodations are magnificent."
extradesc.keywords: framed magazine Hor Ryfic Hotel emblazoned facade

roomecho.desc: A high-pitched howl bounces off the walls.

room.name: Hotel landing
room.desc: Sheeny, ebony wood sprawls across the floor, sweeps up the wall, and stretches across the ceiling sprinkled with solid-gold stars the size of budding roses. A flaxen hue is diffused from these scintillating, sparkling luminaries. A golden runner softens all footfalls. A recess in the northern wall embraces a gently hovering, glass globe. Upon the red door, leading into the honeymoon suite to the southwest, a ceramic pair of lips are smiling. There are two sets of pristine, black marble doors allowing entrance to the east and the southeast. A curlicue BR is etched upon one set while a decorative DH is upon the other. Through the gold marble, southern door resides a guest room while the stairwell lies east.

extradesc.desc: These ruby-red lips are set in a glossy smile. However, if there is much noise in this landing, they will pucker and issue a soft, "Shhhhh."
extradesc.keywords: ceramic pair lips smiling smile red door

extradesc.desc: Inside the globe an explosion of dazzling flames fades into glowing cinders. From the embers a slender, pallid-grey Ashwinder materializes. Its flaming red eyes flash as it circles the sphere, finally resting and laying a crimson egg. As the egg is laid the snake disintegrates into a mound of ash. A flash of blazing flames erupts as the egg opens.

room.name: Quickened Steps Ballroom
room.desc: This cavernous room boasts an ebony, parquet floor inlaid with diagonal slats of ivory and onyx. The stunning, geometric design is so dazzling it makes the floor appear three-dimensional. The ceiling is comprised solely of onyx while the walls are of the purest ivory. An enormous, crystal chandelier stretches its arms wide. Peppered about the room are paintings and portraits. Along the east wall is a band stand made of a diagonal piece of ivory and a mirroring piece of onyx. The exit is to the west through the black marble doors.

extradesc.desc: MAKE THIS AN OBJECT This vast chandelier, comprised of sparkling crystal, is the size of two men laying head to toe. Each arm holds a glass bulb encasing a single, eternal flame. Strings of diamonds hang from the base of the chandelier.

Many framed paintings adorn the walls. One picture depicts a couple dancing. One portrait is of a frowning dowager, Malefique Lenoir; another of a coquette, Sable Lacoeur; and, last, of Ruddy Sang, a commanding man. To examine these paintings, one must look closer.

MAKE THIS AN OBJECT A brushed silver frame encompasses this elderly woman's face. Though her silver hair bespeaks her age, her wrinkled face is stately and dignified. Her perpetual frown extends to her pale, grey eyes that cast an aristocratic glare.

MAKE THIS AN OBJECT Framed in a silver braid, the painting depicts a lissome, willowy woman wearing a pitch-dark dress that accentuates her pale skin. Like blood spurting from a vein, her long, red hair slashes across the canvas as she is whirled around by her partner. He has raven hair and is wearing black pants with a white, dinner jacket and a black, bow tie. This dyad are entwined in an undying waltz.

MAKE THIS AN OBJECT A ruby red frame encapsulates this voluptuous siren. This ebon-haired vixen keeps her enchanting, dark eyes narrowed amorously and her crimson lips in a magnetic smile. * With this paintinga player will look at the picture and s/he will begin to lose strength, forced to keep staring, entranced by this portrait. This can be broken by simple hexes or Stupefying Charm.
Encased by a redwood frame, this man has a strapping, athletic build and flaming-red hair. His jade green eyes twinkle and his freckles dance around his sly smile.

room.name: Intermerate Sanguineous Suite
room.desc: This suite is titanic in both opulence and dimension. Hanging from the vaulted ceiling, running the gamut from the northern door to the distant southern wall in the bedroom, are three chandeliers. The chandelier in the lavish entertainment area is fashioned from diamonds and amethysts. Orchid-shaped flames, their light striking off the jewels, produce kaleidoscopic prisms onto the Rainforest Gold marble walls. The Rosso Verona marble floors house a diamond-shaped pool as well as an assortment of violaceous sofas, settees, divans, and chaises. A solid-gold archway to the south allows access into the Sanctuary of Slumber.

extradesc.desc: These assorted pieces are regal with their deep purple velvet and luxuriously plump cushions. Gold pillows are thrown here and there.
It's as if the diamond shape of this pool adds to the sparkling, twinkling, clear-blue water. These magical waters are warm, yet refreshing, and all instantly dry as they exit this aperture.
This elaborate candelabrum is bedecked with large, twinkling diamonds and amethysts. The refracted light casts miniature rainbows across the room

room.name: The Velveteen Room
room.desc: Black velvet drapes from the ceiling and across the walls. A silver chandelier, clasping golden tapers, emits a honeyed hue that plays with the stretched, dark shadows throughout the room. Rubies line the base of the chandelier. Thick, sumptuous, black carpet muffles all sound by pillowing the feet that walk upon it. The room is dead -devoid of sound or movement- like a padded room. The silver bed supports black satin sheets and blanket, while the gold headboard sports large, bright rubies. To the northwest lies an ebony door that leads to the landing.

extradesc.desc: This silver chandelier is able to hang from gold chains. Golden tapers fit snugly into each of the branches the chandelier offers. Along the base of the chandelier are eye-shaped rubies that blink every so often.
The smooth, solid gold headboard shimmers in the light due to its being buffed to a high sheen. Sizeable, eye-shaped rubies are sprinkled across the headboard and blink and twinkle in the light.

room.name: Viridian Guest Room
room.desc: From the viridian ceiling hang two stained glass lamps casting multi-coloured rays upon the ebony walls and floor. A large bed, with a golden, ornately etched headboard, is adorned with a royal blue duvet. A walnut wardrobe sits in the south-west corner. A plush, azure rug is nestled in front of the bed, though an occasional ember pops from the grey slate fireplace in the western wall. A blood red, leather armchair, with a matching ottoman, is settled by the hearth allowing one warmth or light. A book lies open on the walnut end table. The exit is to the north-east.

extradesc.desc: An engraved scene of wizard hegemony and supremacy is illustrated here. Some wizards are forcing Muggles to circle in the air well above them. Others are throwing flames from their wands at running goblins. House-elves are cowering and pleading on bent knees to the sneering wizards. Two dragons are depicted vanquished by a group of laughing wizards.

This crimson, leather-bound book has gilt lettering upon its spine reading, "The Dark Arts, Is This a Subjective Term?" However, when one attempts to touch it, it flutters across the table, refusing to be touched. Once a person states, "Read to me," the book flips open and a sonorous voice begins to read. "Is the term 'Dark Arts' open to interpretation? Is one person's dark as pitch as another person's black"

The wardrobe is comprised of polished walnut and is large enough to hold an adult male. Carved along its edges are all-seeing eyes that blink upon occasion. Two, gold, vesica pisces-shaped knobs sit upon the doors.

room.name: Hor Ryfic Honeymoon Suite
room.desc: Crimson walls and ceiling surround the mahogany floor. A golden, four-poster bed cradles a ruby-coloured coverlet and canopy. Rose-gold hearts adorn the posts and scarlet hearts decorate the honey-coloured rug relaxing by the bed. In front of the Caen-stone fireplace, two gold chairs sit peacefully with one another. A small chandelier, embracing red tapers, emits a warm, cherry-coloured light. A chestnut armoire rests along the west wall. The exit is to the northeast.

extradesc.desc: Two heart-shaped handles dangle from the heart-etched doors. The chestnut armoire cuddles an ample drawer possessing a heart-shaped knob.

The golden posts stand ten feet tall, swathed with a garnet-coloured, satin canopy. A ruby-coloured, velvet coverlet envelops the downy mattress. Rose-coloured gold, fashioned into petite hearts, grace the posts.
extradesc.keywords: golden four-poster four poster bed hearts rose-gold rose gold

room.name: The Moirae Room
room.desc: Upon the blond, parkay floor, inhabiting this capacious dining hall, stands a grand, elaborately carved table. Regal chairs accompany the immense table. Upon the ceiling is a bewitched fresco. It depicts the table and chairs beneath in painted perfection. As one enters the room, a painted replica is mimicked above. The walls are indigo blue with silhouettes of three women, swaying slowly to some unheard tune. These etched creatures hold golden threads in their hands, lighting the room in a honeyed glow, that twirl and eddy with their movements. Above the northwest door is a portrait of a raven-haired woman.

extradesc.desc: This maple table easily seats sixty people. Carved along the outer edge of the table, the same pattern is repeated. A thread of gold curling around golden shears. The chairs are designed from the same heavy wood as the table. The backs of the chairs stand as tall as a grown man. Engraved onto the backs of each chair are the same golden threads and abhorred shears as on the table top.
extradesc.keywords: table elaborately carved grand chairs regal

extradesc.desc: This fresco flawlessly mirrors all objects and inhabitants in this room.
A honey-coloured frame surrounds this dark beauty. Her hazel, serene eyes observe the actions below her. Cerulean robes flow around her and she holds a pair of golden shears in her right hand.

room.name: Blunkett's Rare Books Cellar
room.desc: The air here is thick, stale, and ancient. A few begrimed lanterns peer through the tenebrous haze in this diminutive and dilapidated cellar. A tiny counter, made of dark walnut, sits in the back. The soiled wood of the counter matches the sullied panelling on the walls. Four ornate, ebony bookshelves contain a motley set of books on the Dark Arts. One slender volume, hot to the touch, is titled "Incendiary Incantations: Ways to Roast Your Victims From the Inside Out". A blood-red vade mecum is labeled "How to Gut Animals, Humans, and Other Magical Creatures". Upon a rickety stand sits an extensive codex, the words "Prt M Hrw" etched into its solid-gold cover. Dust falls from the rotting beams above, covering everything in a filthy residue. A stone staircase spirals upwards to the main shop.

exit.name: up
exit.description: The staircase leads up to the main shop front.

extradesc.desc: This slim text glows white from the candent heat radiating from it. When opened, the book throws flames into the air before allowing the spells to appear. Page fourteen displays the incantation "'Conflagrare Intestinum'- chant the words: "Incendium. Incendium. Conflagrare (victim's name here). Conflagrare (victim's name here). Accendo!" To use this charm one must use your wand thusly: circle once above your head clockwise. Slash to the right, then to the left. Circle back..." A colophon of a snake encircling a scythe is stamped on the back cover.

This ebony stand can barely hold the weight of this golden tome. The appellation "Prt M Hrw" is the Egyptian name for "Coming Forth by Day", or, as it is more commonly known, "The Book of the Dead". It is broken up into spells, or chapters, such as "Making the Transformation Into the Serpent Sata" and "Not Dying a Second Time".
extradesc.keywords: stand gold solid-gold codex Prt Hrw

extradesc.desc: This blood-red handbook oozes a foul, garnet-coloured substance from its spine. Though moist to the touch, all traces of the ichor disappear from your hands immediately after you release the volume. A picture on page six demonstrates the correct way to dismember a house-elf for its valuable spleen. The instructions are as follows: "First one must procure a solid-silver knife. To test its sharpness, place a strand of your hair upon the blade; it should sever the strand in two by its own weight. Begin the incision from the hollow of the neck, slicing down to the navel. Ensure that you've cut through all the fibrous muscles and membranes before..." A colophon of an eye, darkened with tears, is inscribed on the back cover.
extradesc.keywords: blood-red blood red vade mecum gut animals humans magical creatures

roomecho.desc: A shower of dirt falls from the decrepit ceiling, further obscuring the rare tomes.

room.name: FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - The Printing Room
room.desc: The printing room has an atmosphere like that of a basement. Grey stone tiles stretch out here, the short ceiling clashing with the rest of the buildings grandeur. The plain white ceiling comes just low enough to graze a tall mans hair. Torches are hooked onto the wall once every five floor stones, giving the room a dim glow. Near endless rows of mahogany desks almost disappear in the middle of the room, near void of the light from the walls. Each desk has no chair, no candle and only has a stack of parchment and a violet quill. One desk is off from the regimented rows, against the wall adjacent the eastern exit. The only thing that takes this desk apart from all of the others is the lack of a stack of paper and the quill is dark red. A door to the south is unmarked and the exit to the rotunda of the Prophet is to the east.

room.name: The Daily Prophet - East Wing - Second Floor
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - East Wing - Office
room.desc: Behind the dark cherrywood and the fogged glass is a simple office. Two simple wooden chairs with their backs to the door are here, sitting in front of a basic square desk. Behind the desk is a chair, appearing more comfortable than the two in front of the desk. In the back right corner are two filing cabinets, made of cool grey metal. One small window at the back is framed in the same cherrywood as the door.

extradesc.desc: Looking out the window on a clear day gives a nice view of London, and nearer, a not so nice look of the back alleys of Diagon.

room.name: FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - East Wing - Office
The Daily Prophet - First Floor - West Wing
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Rotunda - Second Floor
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - East Wing Hallway
FIRST DRAFT - The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - Conference Room One
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - Conference Room Two
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - Interview Room
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - West Wing Hallway
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - West Wing - Development
FIRST DRAFT - The Daily Prophet - Second Floor - West Wing - Staff Lounge
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Rotunda - Third Floor
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Third Floor - Eastern Hallway
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Third Floor - Western Hallway
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Rotunda - Fourth Floor
FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - Rotunda - Fifth Floor
Oberask Pellinger's Apothecary Shop
room.desc: An overwhelmingly fetid smell saturates this crowded, windowless apothecary, a stomach-churning combination of sulphur, spoilt milk, and singed feathers. Lit intermittently by half a dozen glowing, floating orbs, the walls are covered from the stained, stone floor to the timbered ceiling with overflowing shelves. Stout barrels and chests, some open, some closed, turn this alchemical repository into an impromptu maze; each turning reveals a new, revolting odour and a new glimpse of the jumbled contents of the store. Bundles of herbs, feathers, and other assorted parts, that once belonged to birds, animals, or plants, dangle higgledy-piggledy from ratty-looking twine. Nearly hidden at the back of the store is a stained countertop, behind which stands a tall, glass-fronted cabinet. A heavily knotted, chestnut door to the west leads out into Knockturn Alley.

extradesc.desc: Upon the countertop there are graduated measuring cups made of glass, silver, and gold. A jeweller's loupe sits atop a less-powerful hand-lens. Measuring tapes and rulers of various lengths and precisions are scattered throughout the mess.

These bezoar-sized, luminescent balls drift lazily about the shop, some hovering over the counter, others bobbing along behind customers. They cast a sickly, jaundiced light, roughly equivalent to that of three candles. Around the equator of each globe are inscribed the words 'Fitzgibbon's Flame-Free Fireflies - Safe for Flammables'.

Held fast by an aberrant, baroque, black padlock, the stained shelves of this cabinet hold potion ingredients too valuable or too dangerous for the eager hands of the public. A group of jars labelled 'Acromantula Venom' in thin, jagged handwriting sit in the top left-hand corner. Another hand-written tag announces that the small iron box contains 'Venomous Tentacula Seeds'. A globular jar, ringed with glowing iron bands, is marked 'Caution: Erumpet Exploding Fluid'. An index card propped next to a pile of greyish conical objects identifies them as 'Erumpet Horns'. In the bottom right-hand corner of the cabinet is a small, unlabeled vial of something that glimmers with silvery reflections in the faint light.
The door is a heavy slab of gnarled wood, deeply stained an infernal red. Above the doorway hangs a collection of small cages containing doxies, fairies, and imps.

The original shade of the battered, marble countertop is indiscernible under years of stains and discolouration. A variety of instruments for measuring, weighing, and evaluating ingredients take up almost the whole surface. A set of brass scales towers over most of the mess.

roomecho.desc: The lid of a nearby barrel lifts slightly, briefly revealing a wicked-looking pair of amber eyes before slamming shut.

room.name: Quality Quidditch Supplies - Upper Storeroom
room.desc: The floors are invisible behind this room's mounting piles of boxes wrapped in twine. Each box has its own label listin its contents, ranging from robes to broomsticks. There is a fireplace roaring on the west wall and the staircase on the northwall leads both up and down.

room.name: Roof of Quality Quidditch Supplies
room.desc: The flat granite roof of Quality Quidditch Supplies is fairly bare, with only two objects of notice. One is a locked trap door in the floor, leading into Quality Quidditch Supplies The second is a broom hitch where those who arrive to Diagon by broomstick may dock their brooms. Diagon stretches out westward, to the point of not being visible.

room.name: Ebonizing Artistry
room.desc: The walls of this gallery are draped in black velvet curtains. Long enough to collect in rich folds, spilling over the polished, grey marble floor, the thick fabric deadens all sound in the room. Evenly spaced along the narrow, rectangular hall, several niches display artworks and sculptures. In the north-eastern corner, a counter, constructed of the same mirror-finished marble as the floor, juts protectively before a stone, spiral staircase. A subtle, brushed-brass plaque at the base of the stairs reads, "Studio - Access by Appointment Only". Pure, saffron light issues from golden, filigreed spheres, levitating near the high ceiling. A matte-black door to the south leads out to the street.

extradesc.desc: Each niche holds a unique work of art accompanied by a brushed brass plaque bearing details of the piece. Paintings are hung in simple, dignified frames, while statues, sculptures, and busts rest atop velvet-draped pedestals. The curtains of some recesses are drawn shut, removing their contents from view. The golden spheres lighting the room are positioned to cast a flattering, even glow into each niche.

On closer examination, it is apparent that these delicate orbs of golden lace are actually cages. They crackle with the potent magic required to contain their occupants - untamed phoenixes. The incandescent birds have no room to even spread their wings, limited solely to their intricately-sculpted perches. The torment in their liquid eyes is tangible. Many of them weep silently and without pause, their precious tears collecting in cut-crystal vials that dangle beneath each sphere.
extradesc.keywords: pure saffron light golden filigreed levitating spheres up ceiling glow

extradesc.desc: Hanging from the ceiling, these heavy, light-absorbing sheets of shadow serve to remove the walls from memory. They leave the impression that you are in a gallery amidst a limitless void, as though nothing else matters but the pieces themselves.
The slim, black door, tastefully adorned with an old-fashioned handle made of brushed brass, leads south to the street.

roomecho.desc: Hauntingly-beautiful music rises from one of the hovering spheres. Agonizingly sad, it soon trails off into silence.

room.name: Sanctuary of Slumber
room.desc: A golden chandelier, adorned with shimmering pearls, dangles in the archway and bestows light upon the glossy, Rainforest Gold marble walls and the Rosso Verona marble floors. A second, burnished, topaz-encrusted, bronze, elegant chandelier, hanging over the ample bed, emits a warm hue. Draped with copper-coloured, silk sheets and a dark sable coverlet, the mattress is sumptuous and charmed to bless the sleeper with tranquil slumber. A plush, rich mink-covered chair is coupled with a small, bronze table along with a leather-bound book. The gold fireplace houses crackling flames and a hint of lilies lingers in the air. The solid-gold, northern arch, granting access to these opulent accommodations, also allows one admission to the palatial, outer suite.

extradesc.desc: Both of these exquisite light fixtures bequeath warm, gentle illumination upon all around it.
The sable is luscious to the touch, exuding the perfumed scent of lavender when brushed across.
extradesc.keywords: bed copper copper-coloured silk sheets sable coverlet mattress

extradesc.desc: The book's cover is claret-coloured, its pages gilded. In gilt lettering, the title reads: "'Royal is the Colour of Our Blood' by Tru Plenary."

roomecho.desc: A trace of lilies wafts by.

room.name: Junk Room (`YHave MOB Purge after Dumping`X)
Diagon Alley - Back Alley
room.desc: The back alley turns here, into a long stretch running behind the main shops of Diagon. Pieces of rubbish blow about, rats skitter across occasionally and graffiti adorns the walls. The battered and broken cobblestone of the alley stretches off to the east, and the only visible way back to Diagon is to the south.

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind a Shop
room.desc: The beaten back alley continues on here, running behind a simple brick building. A small grey door of metal has a warning written on it, "Staff Use only, DO NOT ENTER". Along the north wall is random graffiti written. The alley stretches off to the east and west.

extradesc.desc:
. Graffiti is sprawled here, ranging in various messages: One written in red ink reads, "GOBLINS ARE..." and then trails off into profanity.
Another one in faded, curly green lettering says, "Fudge's a bungler!"
Another states rather boldly in black writing, "ALL YOU MUDBLOODS WILL RUE THE DAY!"

room.name: WWN - Main Hallway
room.desc: The hallway continues on in the same form of the lobby. The granite stretches east and west leading to more cedar doors. To the south the door reads, "Broadcasting Beacon" and has a very thick lock on the door. To the north is the lobby and the exit back to Diagon Alley.

room.name: WWN - Main Hallway - Western End
room.desc: The hallway continues on in the same form of the lobby. The granite stretches east leading to more cedar doors. A mural occupies the entire north wall showing off a beautiful chateau with green rolling hills surround it. The door to the south has a black plaque on it that reads, "Loo".

room.name: Keen Magpie - Back Hallway
room.desc: One might wonder why this room is marked off limits. Stretching from the "STAFF ONLY" Door in the bar is a red oak hallway, with the dark red wood covering the floors, and the bottom half of the walls. On the blank wallpaper of the upper walls and ceilings are simple bronze sconces that dimly light the room. The only object that can be seen in the whole of the hallway is a small statue of a magpie on a pedestal. To the south is the only available exit, back to the Keen Magpie.

room.name: Room Three
room.desc: This room is quite simply decorated, wooden panels have been nailed straight to drywall, bronze sconces with white lamp covers screwed into the wood panels and a square, plain, red rug adorns the cedar floor. A bare square fireplace is set into the south wall with a small unstill life of a bowl of fruit above its mantle. A rectangle spartan bed with a red cover is pushed against the north wall and aside it is a plain cedar dresser. To the west is the door back to the hallway and to the east is the bathroom for Room Three.

room.name: Room Three - Bathroom
room.desc: The bathroom of Room Three is hardly more lavish than the bedroom. A white tiled floor is surmounted by a similarly tiled tub and sink. A dome of light hangs from the ceiling with no apparent way to turn it off. A wooden framed mirror is nailed to the wall above the sink. There is no window in the room, but the sounds of traffic still leak through.

room.name: Daily Prophet News Room
room.desc: This room is all business, but with a very old feeling to it. The floors of stone look as though they might have once held a pattern which has been rubbed off by centuries of wizards rushing around it. The room is dominated by ten simple rectangular desks, really more like large blocks of wood with a finish and drawers. Each is numbered with a small bronze plaque. Each has faded writing on it, all names and positions as if the staff got tired of changing names and just assigned numbers. Each desk has its own light for late night use but overhead is a huge assembly of candles floating to light the room. A large marble skull on an attatched pedestal near the door faces upwards with a candle in its mouth. To the west is the way back to the Daily Prophet office, and indirectly the way to leave the huge tower.

room.name: The Daily Prophet - Rotunda - First Floor
room.desc: The curving path of the Daily Prophet's main staircase pulls up here and stops on the second floor platform. On the west wall is a painting hanging from the rounded wall of the rotunda. To the east and west a corridor stretch off into a slew of doors. On the eastern side of the rotunda floor is the continuation of the rotunda staircase, leading upwards. Down a deadly jump or the staircase is the main floor of the Daily Prophet and subsequently, Diagon Alley.

room.name: FIRST DRAFT The Daily Prophet - First Floor - East Wing
room.desc: The green marble path of the lobby continues here, but the matching walls give way to a swirling white pattern on the walls. Dark cherrywood molding lines the walls on its lines with the marble floor and white ceiling. Two doors, on opposite sides of the hallways match the molding's wood. Beset in the doors is a panel of frosted glass with the name of the occupant written on the glass in loopy letters. The hallway of offices goes off to the east and further to the west and the rotunda and sloping access to the exit is to the west.

extradesc.desc: The curly words on the fogged glass to the north reads, "Vacant".
The curly words on the fogged glass to the south reads, "Vacant".

room.name: Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Behind SandWitches
room.desc: The back alley ends abruptly here, against a huge wall to the west and north, and the back of a store to the south. The southern wall has a small sign above a small green door that reads, "SandWitches - Best Sandwiches in all of London - Please use FRONT door". Stretching over the western wall is the huge Gringotts building, it's pearly exterior shining in the sun and faintly glowing at night. The back alley is east, running north.

room.name: Basement Storage - Shop East of Madam Malkins
Diagon Alley - Back Alley - Riley's Rat Emporium
room.desc: This slanted, old, wooden shack is covered in inches upon inches of thick dust and by dry rat droppings. It is filled with old, rusty cages, the doors of which are swung open, the locks either broken or open. Broken-down, wooden chairs and tables underneath them are scarred by bite and chew marks thrown randomly across their surfaces. Something stands out amidst the ruin: a metal sign atop a metal pole planted right in the middle of the room. The only light comes during the day, through a southern window so deeply covered in dust and grease that it is barely noticeable. Moss and dark-green, damp plants crawl from underneath the confines of a heavy, southern door, fighting an unpredictable battle with the dry dust upon the ground.

extradesc.desc:
. The simple sign reads:
THIS SITE UNDER THE PROTECTION OF WACC, WIZARDS FOR AMIABLE CARE OF CREATURES. THIS IS THE NESTING PLACE OF THE RARE NORTHWESTERN LONG-TAILED SCOTTISH RAT, ANY HARMING OF RATS WILL INCUR LEGAL PENALTIES.

The Leaky Cauldron - Room Ten - Bedroom
The Leaky Cauldron - Room Ten - Bathroom
Wireless Wizarding Network - Back Hallway - East End
room.desc: The hallway of the WWN ends here, with three simple offices. Each has a wooden door with fogged glass, the wood stained almost to a bronze color. Each doorknob is modeled in the shape of a musical note, the black metal curling into a cleff. A keyhole is set in the doors, allowing access to the offices. The hallway continues on to the west, also the way back out to Diagon Alley.

room.name: WWN - Broadcasting Beacon Base
room.desc: The narrow hallway opens into a very different, almost surreal location. The walls reach up into the sky with no ceiling. A great twisting spire rises up out of the glazed glass ground and spins into the sky. It's tendril-shaped rainbow colored surface looks as if it were grown out of coral rather than built. In it's base are roughly-hewn entrances made with doors emplaced within them. The entire spire seems to glow and hum like a muggle machine. Many wizards shuffle about, especially around the spire and a locked off shack next to it. A sign on the shack reads, "DONT TOUCH ANYTHING YOU DONT KNOW WHAT DOES. -Mgmt." The only exit out of this is back to the north to the hallway.

room.name: The Leaky Cauldron - Room Eleven - Bathroom
The Leaky Cauldron - Room Twelve - Bedroom
The Leaky Cauldron - Room Twelve - Bathroom
FIRST DRAFT A Magi's Mechanisms - Astronomy Division
room.desc: The crisp air in this room is that of an autumn evening. Where the walls and ceiling would be there is only clear night sky, the stars twinkling like diamonds. The floor is actually grass, tangled in green masses and covered in dew. Set at intervals throughout this room are telescopes, pointed up towards a specific star, planet, or the faux moon upon the dark sky. Multiple tables are also scattered about, showing models of the universe, astrolabes, and various other astronomy related tools of witches and wizards. Sticking out like a sore thumb, a staircase leads downward, to the main storefront of A Magi's Mechanisms.

extradesc.desc: The sky is unbelievably realistic. The dark expanse seems just as intangible and impalpable as the real night sky. Stars and planets beam like tiny pinpricks of light in a black-paper screen. They are, however, dwarfed by the waning moon, the shocked face of Luna staring back with uneasy realism. If touched, the surrounding, invisible walls feel like the impenetrable rushes of a waterfall.

roomecho.desc: The crickets play their endless tune, it fading off into the night.
A cool wind blows through the room, feeling like tiny icicles cutting at your face.
